questions.explanation: Amphibian metamorphosis is one of the most dramatic post-embryonic developmental events in vertebrates, entirely orchestrated by thyroid hormones: (1) Thyroid hormone (TH): The onset of metamorphosis is triggered by a surge in circulating T3 (triiodothyronine) and T4 (thyroxine), produced by the thyroid gland under stimulation from TSH (from the pituitary) and ultimately TRH (from the hypothalamus). TH levels rise progressively during prometamorphosis and peak during metamorphic climax. (2) Mechanism: TH binds to thyroid hormone receptors (TRalpha and TRbeta), which are nuclear receptors that act as ligand-dependent transcription factors. Unliganded TRs repress target genes (maintaining the larval state); upon TH binding, TRs recruit coactivators and activate metamorphic gene programs. (3) Tissue-specific responses: Remarkably, the same hormone produces opposite effects in different tissues: (a) Limbs — TH stimulates cell proliferation and morphogenesis, growing the legs; (b) Tail — TH induces apoptosis and tissue resorption, eliminating the tail; (c) Intestine — the larval gut (simple herbivore intestine) undergoes massive remodeling to a shorter, more complex carnivore gut via apoptosis of larval epithelium and proliferation of adult stem cells; (d) Skin — transition from larval to adult skin with mucous glands; (e) Hemoglobin — switch from larval hemoglobin (higher O2 affinity for aquatic respiration) to adult hemoglobin (optimized for air breathing); (f) Brain — remodeling of the visual system from lateral-eyed to binocular. (4) Proof: Thyroidectomy prevents metamorphosis. Treatment of tadpoles with exogenous TH induces precocious metamorphosis. Blocking TH synthesis with propylthiouracil halts metamorphosis.

questions.question: Polycomb group (PcG) and Trithorax group (TrxG) proteins maintain gene expression states established during development. How do they function?
options: PcG proteins activate all genes while TrxG proteins repress all genes
PcG and TrxG are transcription factors that bind to promoters and directly control RNA polymerase activity

PcG proteins maintain gene silencing through histone H3K27 trimethylation (by PRC2 complex) and chromatin compaction (by PRC1 complex), while TrxG proteins maintain gene activation through histone H3K4 trimethylation and chromatin opening — together they ensure that cell identity is stably inherited through cell divisions
Both PcG and TrxG modify DNA sequence directly to control gene expression
questions.explanation: PcG and TrxG proteins form an epigenetic memory system that maintains developmental gene expression patterns: (1) Polycomb Repressive Complexes: PRC2 (core: EZH2/EZH1, SUZ12, EED) is a histone methyltransferase that catalyzes H3K27me3 (trimethylation of histone H3 lysine 27), a repressive histone mark. PRC1 (core: RING1A/B, BMI1, CBX) recognizes H3K27me3 through the CBX chromodomain, ubiquitinates histone H2A at lysine 119 (H2AK119ub), and mediates chromatin compaction. Together, PRC1 and PRC2 maintain transcriptional silencing of developmental genes (especially Hox genes) in cells where those genes should remain off. (2) Trithorax complexes: TrxG proteins include the MLL/COMPASS complex (catalyzes H3K4me3, an activating mark), SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complexes (use ATP to slide nucleosomes and open chromatin), and Mediator complex. These maintain active transcription of developmental genes in cells where those genes should remain on. (3) Bistable switch: The PcG/TrxG system creates a bistable epigenetic switch at each developmental gene locus — once a gene is silenced (PcG-marked) or activated (TrxG-marked) during development, that state is maintained through subsequent cell divisions. (4) Hox gene regulation: The most studied PcG/TrxG targets are Hox genes. PcG mutations cause posterior homeotic transformations (derepression of posterior Hox genes in anterior segments), while TrxG mutations cause anterior transformations (failure to maintain Hox expression). (5) Cancer: EZH2 is overexpressed in many cancers, and EZH2 inhibitors (tazemetostat) are used in cancer therapy. MLL translocations cause aggressive leukemias.

questions.question: The formation of the three germ layers during gastrulation is a fundamental event in animal development. Which correctly matches each germ layer with its derivatives?
options: Ectoderm gives rise to muscle, mesoderm gives rise to nerves, endoderm gives rise to skin

Ectoderm gives rise to the nervous system and epidermis; mesoderm gives rise to muscle, skeleton, cardiovascular system, and kidneys; endoderm gives rise to the digestive tract lining, liver, pancreas, and respiratory epithelium
All three germ layers produce identical cell types with complete interchangeability
Endoderm gives rise to all external structures while ectoderm gives rise to all internal organs
questions.explanation: Germ layer fate specification is highly conserved across triploblastic animals: (1) Ectoderm (outermost layer): The ectoderm gives rise to: (a) Surface ectoderm — epidermis (skin), hair, nails, sweat glands, mammary glands, tooth enamel, lens of the eye, anterior pituitary (Rathke's pouch); (b) Neuroectoderm — entire central nervous system (brain, spinal cord, retina), neural crest cells (which produce peripheral nervous system, melanocytes, craniofacial skeleton, adrenal medulla); (c) Sensory placodes — lens, otic vesicle (inner ear), olfactory epithelium. (2) Mesoderm (middle layer): Mesoderm gives rise to: (a) Axial mesoderm — notochord (later nucleus pulposus); (b) Paraxial mesoderm — somites → skeletal muscle, vertebrae, ribs, dermis of the back; (c) Intermediate mesoderm — kidneys, ureters, gonads, adrenal cortex; (d) Lateral plate mesoderm — cardiovascular system (heart, blood vessels, blood), smooth muscle, body wall, limb skeleton, serous membranes (pleura, peritoneum), spleen. (3) Endoderm (innermost layer): Endoderm gives rise to: (a) Epithelial lining of the digestive tract (pharynx to rectum); (b) Liver and pancreas (as outgrowths of foregut endoderm); (c) Respiratory epithelium (lungs, trachea — as ventral outgrowth of foregut); (d) Thyroid, parathyroid, thymus (from pharyngeal pouch endoderm); (e) Urinary bladder and urethra lining. (4) Exceptions: Neural crest cells, derived from ectoderm, produce many mesenchymal derivatives (bone, cartilage) normally associated with mesoderm — they are sometimes called the 'fourth germ layer.'

questions.question: A researcher wants to create a fate map of the early zebrafish embryo to determine which cells contribute to which adult structures. Which technique would provide the most precise single-cell resolution fate map?
options: Inject individual blastomeres with a fluorescent lineage tracer (such as fluorescein-dextran or photoconvertible fluorescent proteins like Kaede), then follow the labeled cells and their descendants through development using confocal microscopy to determine which tissues they contribute to
Remove individual cells and observe which structures are missing
Observe embryos under a standard microscope and infer cell fates from position
Stain all cells with the same dye and observe color changes
questions.explanation: Fate mapping is the cornerstone of understanding embryonic development and has evolved from classical to modern techniques: (1) Fluorescent lineage tracers: Injecting fluorescein-dextran (a large, cell-impermeant molecule that is inherited by all daughter cells) or rhodamine-dextran into individual blastomeres at specific stages labels that cell and all its progeny permanently. Using confocal time-lapse microscopy, the researcher can follow labeled cells throughout development and determine their final tissue contributions. (2) Photoconvertible proteins: Kaede protein (from the stony coral Trachyphyllia geoffroyi) converts from green to red fluorescence upon UV exposure. By expressing Kaede ubiquitously and photoconverting specific cells at defined stages, researchers can mark cells without injection. The red-converted cells and their descendants are distinguishable from unconverted cells. More advanced versions (KikGR, Dendra2, mEos) offer reversible or sequential conversion. (3) Genetic approaches: Cre-loxP lineage tracing uses tissue-specific Cre drivers to permanently activate a reporter (like GFP from a Rosa26 locus) in specific cell populations. CreERT2 (tamoxifen-inducible) adds temporal control. These approaches are widely used in mouse development. (4) Why zebrafish: Zebrafish embryos are transparent (allowing live imaging), develop externally, have a short generation time (3 months), and are genetically tractable. (5) Classic fate maps: Fate maps of Xenopus (Dale and Slack, 1987) and zebrafish (Kimmel et al., 1990) were foundational. They revealed that cell fates are largely predictable at the 32-cell stage but show some mixing, indicating regulative capacity. (6) Option D (cell ablation) reveals necessity, not normal fate — a cell that is needed for a structure may not normally contribute to it.

questions.question: What is the role of FGF signaling in mesoderm induction during vertebrate embryogenesis?
options: FGF acts exclusively on endoderm with no role in mesoderm
FGF signaling replaces Nodal entirely and is the sole mesoderm inducer
FGF inhibits all mesoderm formation and promotes ectoderm exclusively

FGF signaling cooperates with Nodal/Activin signaling to induce and pattern mesoderm — FGF is required for mesoderm maintenance and posterior mesoderm specification, while Nodal provides the primary inductive signal with high Nodal levels specifying dorsal mesoderm (organizer) and low levels specifying ventral mesoderm
questions.explanation: Mesoderm induction involves the interplay of multiple signaling pathways: (1) Nodal as primary inducer: Nodal (a TGF-beta superfamily member) is the primary mesoderm-inducing signal. In Xenopus, maternal VegT activates Nodal-related genes (Xnr1-6) in the vegetal hemisphere. Nodal acts in a concentration-dependent manner — high Nodal levels induce dorsal/anterior mesoderm (organizer: notochord, head mesoderm), medium levels induce lateral mesoderm (somites, kidney), and low levels induce ventral mesoderm (blood, lateral plate). (2) FGF cooperation: FGF signaling (primarily FGF4 and FGF8, acting through FGFR1/MAPK-ERK pathway) is required for mesoderm to be induced and maintained: (a) Competence: FGF signaling makes ectoderm competent to respond to Nodal. Blocking FGF prevents Nodal-induced mesoderm formation. (b) Maintenance: FGF maintains mesodermal gene expression — cells induced by Nodal revert to ectodermal fate if FGF is subsequently blocked. (c) Posterior specification: FGF promotes posterior mesodermal fates. High FGF levels specify posterior mesoderm (tail structures), while low FGF allows anterior mesoderm fates. (3) BMP modulation: BMP4/7 (another TGF-beta family member) patterns the mesoderm along the dorsal-ventral axis. High BMP promotes ventral mesoderm (blood), low BMP (due to organizer-secreted antagonists) promotes dorsal mesoderm (notochord, muscle). (4) Integration: The combination of Nodal level, FGF signaling strength, BMP activity, and Wnt signaling collectively specifies the many mesodermal subtypes.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about cleavage patterns across different animal groups:
(I) Radial holoblastic cleavage (equal, symmetrical divisions through the entire egg) is characteristic of sea urchins and amphibians.
(II) Spiral holoblastic cleavage, where successive cleavage planes are tilted obliquely, is characteristic of most mollusks and annelids.
(III) Discoidal meroblastic cleavage (cell division restricted to a small disc at the animal pole) occurs in birds and reptiles due to the large yolk mass preventing complete cell division.
(IV) Superficial cleavage (nuclear division without cytokinesis, forming a syncytium) is unique to mammals and does not occur in insects.
options: True
True
True
False
questions.explanation: Analysis of each statement: (I) TRUE — Radial holoblastic cleavage occurs in eggs with relatively little yolk (isolecithal to moderately telolecithal). In sea urchins, cleavage is radial and initially equal. In amphibians (Xenopus), cleavage is radial but unequal — the vegetal hemisphere contains more yolk, so vegetal blastomeres are larger (macromeres) than animal blastomeres (micromeres). The cleavage furrow passes completely through the egg in both cases (holoblastic). (II) TRUE — Spiral cleavage is a highly derived cleavage pattern found in the Spiralia clade (mollusks, annelids, nemerteans, flatworms, and some other lophotrochozoans). Each cleavage plane is tilted approximately 45 degrees from the animal-vegetal axis, with the direction alternating between dextral (clockwise) and sinistral (counterclockwise). This produces daughter cells that sit in the furrows between their sister cells, creating a characteristic spiral arrangement. Spiral cleavage is highly deterministic — the fate of each blastomere is predictable based on its position in the spiral pattern. (III) TRUE — Birds, reptiles, and most fish have telolecithal eggs with massive yolk deposits. Cleavage furrows cannot penetrate the dense yolk, so cell division is restricted to a small blastodisc at the animal pole (meroblastic discoidal cleavage). The result is a flat disc of cells (the blastoderm) sitting atop the undivided yolk mass. (IV) FALSE — Superficial cleavage is characteristic of insects (including Drosophila), NOT mammals. In Drosophila, the fertilized egg undergoes 13 rapid rounds of nuclear division without cytokinesis, creating a syncytial blastoderm with ~6000 nuclei sharing a common cytoplasm. Nuclei then migrate to the periphery and cellularize simultaneously. Mammals have holoblastic rotational cleavage.

questions.question: What is the Turing reaction-diffusion mechanism, and how does it apply to biological pattern formation?
options: Turing mechanism involves direct mechanical forces shaping tissue patterns
A Turing system involves only a single molecule acting uniformly across the tissue

A Turing system involves two diffusible molecules — a short-range activator and a long-range inhibitor — whose interaction spontaneously generates stable periodic patterns (spots, stripes) from initially uniform conditions through local self-activation and lateral inhibition
Turing mechanism requires pre-existing spatial information and cannot generate patterns de novo
questions.explanation: Alan Turing's 1952 paper 'The Chemical Basis of Morphogenesis' proposed a mathematical framework for spontaneous pattern formation: (1) Core concept: Two diffusible morphogens interact — an activator (A) that promotes its own production (positive feedback) and also promotes production of an inhibitor (I), and an inhibitor that represses the activator. The critical requirement is that the inhibitor diffuses faster than the activator (long-range inhibition, short-range activation). (2) Pattern emergence: Starting from a uniform state with small random fluctuations, this system amplifies perturbations — wherever activator is slightly higher, it locally boosts itself while also producing inhibitor that diffuses away and suppresses activator in neighboring regions. This generates stable periodic patterns: spots, stripes, or labyrinthine patterns depending on parameter values. (3) Biological examples: (a) Digit patterning — BMP/Wnt as activator, Sox9 as downstream target, Noggin/FGF as inhibitor, generating periodic digit/interdigit pattern; (b) Hair follicle spacing — Wnt/beta-catenin as activator, DKK/sFRP as inhibitor, generating regular follicle spacing; (c) Feather bud patterning in chick skin; (d) Zebrafish skin pigmentation stripes — interaction between melanophore (black) and xanthophore (yellow) pigment cells; (e) Left-right asymmetry in some models. (4) Mathematical formulation: da/dt = f(a,i) + Da*nabla^2(a); di/dt = g(a,i) + Di*nabla^2(i), where Di >> Da (inhibitor diffuses faster). (5) Verification: Computational modeling predicts specific parameter relationships, and experimental perturbation of component concentrations or diffusion rates produces predicted pattern changes.

questions.question:
A researcher studies the timing and location of Hox gene expression during mouse embryogenesis:

Hox gene | Expression onset (E day) | Anterior expression boundary | Posterior expression | Chromosomal position
Hoxa1 | E7.5 | Rhombomere 4 | Entire posterior | 3' end
Hoxa4 | E8.0 | Cervical somite 1 | Entire posterior | Middle
Hoxa9 | E8.5 | Thoracolumbar junction | Entire posterior | Middle-5'
Hoxa13 | E9.5 | Sacral/caudal region | Most posterior | 5' end

What two principles of Hox gene regulation are demonstrated?
options: Hox gene expression shows no correlation with chromosomal position
All Hox genes are expressed simultaneously in all tissues
5' Hox genes are expressed first and most anteriorly

Spatial colinearity (3' genes have more anterior expression boundaries, 5' genes more posterior) and temporal colinearity (3' genes are activated earlier in development, 5' genes later), with each gene having a sharp anterior boundary but extending throughout the posterior axis
questions.explanation: The data illustrate two fundamental properties of Hox gene organization: (1) Spatial colinearity: The anterior boundary of expression correlates with chromosomal position. Hoxa1 (3' end of cluster) has the most anterior boundary (rhombomere 4 in the hindbrain). Hoxa4 has a more posterior boundary (cervical somite 1). Hoxa9 is further posterior (thoracolumbar junction). Hoxa13 (5' end) has the most posterior boundary (sacral/caudal region). Importantly, each gene is expressed from its anterior boundary through the entire posterior axis — Hox genes show nested, overlapping expression domains with progressively more anterior boundaries as you move 3' in the cluster. (2) Temporal colinearity: 3' genes are activated earlier (Hoxa1 at E7.5) and 5' genes progressively later (Hoxa13 at E9.5). This temporal sequence correlates with body axis elongation — as new somites are added posteriorly, more 5' Hox genes are sequentially activated. (3) Mechanism: Temporal colinearity is linked to progressive chromatin opening from the 3' end of the Hox cluster. Initially, the entire cluster is in a PcG-silenced, compact chromatin state. During development, chromatin at the 3' end opens first (losing H3K27me3, gaining H3K4me3), followed progressively by more 5' regions. This involves the opposition between PcG silencing and TrxG activation, with retinoic acid (RA) and FGF/Wnt signals influencing the rate of chromatin opening. (4) Posterior prevalence: Where expression domains overlap, the most 5' (most recently activated) Hox gene dominates segment specification. (5) Conservation: Both spatial and temporal colinearity are conserved across vertebrates and correlate with the 4-cluster organization (HoxA, B, C, D) arising from whole-genome duplications.

questions.question: What is the role of the primary cilium in Hedgehog (Hh) signaling in vertebrates, and how does this differ from Drosophila?
options: In vertebrates, the primary cilium is essential for Hedgehog signal transduction — Patched localizes to the cilium and inhibits Smoothened; upon Hh ligand binding, Patched exits the cilium, Smoothened enters and activates Gli transcription factors at the cilium tip; this ciliary requirement is absent in Drosophila, which lacks primary cilia on most cells
The primary cilium inhibits all Hedgehog signaling in vertebrates
The primary cilium plays no role in Hedgehog signaling in any organism
Both Drosophila and vertebrates require cilia for Hedgehog signaling
questions.explanation: The requirement for primary cilia in vertebrate Hedgehog signaling was an unexpected discovery that revealed a fundamental difference from Drosophila: (1) Vertebrate Hh signaling at the cilium: In the absence of Hedgehog ligand, the receptor Patched1 (PTCH1) localizes to the primary cilium membrane and prevents Smoothened (SMO) from entering the cilium. Under these conditions, Gli3 (and to some extent Gli2) is processed into a transcriptional repressor (Gli3R) at the cilium base by PKA-mediated phosphorylation and subsequent proteolytic cleavage. (2) Ligand binding: When Shh binds PTCH1, PTCH1 is internalized and degraded (exits the cilium), releasing the inhibition of SMO. SMO then accumulates in the cilium membrane. Active SMO at the cilium tip prevents Gli processing, allowing full-length Gli2 and Gli3 to function as transcriptional activators (GliA). Activated Gli proteins traffic from the cilium to the nucleus. (3) Intraflagellar transport (IFT): IFT proteins (which transport cargo along the ciliary axoneme) are essential for Hh signaling. Mutations in IFT proteins (IFT88, IFT172, Kif3a) cause loss of primary cilia and disrupt Hh signaling, phenocopying Hh pathway mutants. (4) Drosophila difference: Drosophila cells (except sensory neurons) lack primary cilia. Hh signaling in Drosophila occurs at the plasma membrane without ciliary involvement. The downstream pathway components are homologous (Patched, Smoothened, Ci/Gli) but the spatial organization differs fundamentally. (5) Clinical significance: Ciliopathies (diseases of ciliary function, such as Bardet-Biedl syndrome, Joubert syndrome) often show features of disrupted Hedgehog signaling, including polydactyly and craniofacial abnormalities.

questions.question: The blastocyst stage is critical in mammalian development. What event during blastocyst formation determines the first cell lineage decision?
options: Random selection at implantation determines which cells form the embryo

Compaction and polarization at the 8-16 cell morula stage lead to differential allocation of cells to the outer trophectoderm (TE) versus the inner cell mass (ICM), mediated by the Hippo pathway — outer cells with no cell contacts on their apical surface activate YAP/TAZ and express Cdx2 (trophoblast fate), while inner cells activate Hippo signaling, inactivating YAP/TAZ, and express Oct4/Nanog (ICM fate)
All cells of the blastocyst are identical with no lineage differences
Differential gene expression at the 2-cell stage that permanently assigns all cell fates
questions.explanation: The first cell lineage decision in mammals (ICM vs TE) is a paradigm for understanding how cell position drives cell fate: (1) Compaction: At the 8-cell stage, blastomeres increase cell-cell adhesion (via E-cadherin), flatten against each other, and polarize — establishing apical (outward-facing) and basolateral (contact) domains. The apical domain is marked by Par3/Par6/aPKC and apical microvilli. (2) Inside-outside model: During the 8-to-16 and 16-to-32 cell divisions, cells can divide symmetrically (both daughters on the outside) or asymmetrically (one outside, one inside). Outside cells retain apical polarity; inside cells are surrounded by neighbors and lack a free apical surface. (3) Hippo pathway: Cell polarity and position are read by the Hippo signaling pathway. Outside cells: apical domain sequesters the Hippo pathway components (AMOT/Angiomotin associates with the apical domain away from the NF2/Merlin complex), preventing Hippo pathway activation. YAP/TAZ remain unphosphorylated, enter the nucleus, and partner with TEAD4 to activate Cdx2 (the master trophoblast transcription factor). Inside cells: lack of polarity allows NF2/AMOT interaction, activating the Hippo kinase cascade (MST1/2 → LATS1/2 → YAP/TAZ phosphorylation). Phosphorylated YAP/TAZ are retained in the cytoplasm and degraded. Without YAP/TEAD4, Cdx2 is not activated, and Oct4/Sox2/Nanog maintain pluripotency (ICM fate). (4) Mutual repression: Cdx2 and Oct4 mutually repress each other, creating a bistable switch that reinforces the TE vs ICM distinction. (5) Second lineage decision: Within the ICM, a second decision separates epiblast (Oct4/Nanog-high) from primitive endoderm (Gata6/Gata4-high), mediated by FGF4/ERK signaling.

questions.question: Organogenesis involves complex tissue interactions. What is the mechanism of kidney induction in mammals?
options: The kidney forms from a single cell type without any inductive interactions
Neural crest cells migrate to form all kidney structures
The kidney develops entirely from endoderm through self-assembly

Reciprocal induction between the ureteric bud (from the Wolffian duct) and the metanephric mesenchyme — GDNF from mesenchyme attracts and promotes branching of the ureteric bud, while Wnt9b and Wnt11 from the ureteric bud tips induce the mesenchyme to undergo mesenchymal-to-epithelial transition and form nephrons
questions.explanation: Kidney development (metanephric kidney) is the textbook example of reciprocal induction: (1) Initiation: The metanephric mesenchyme (derived from intermediate mesoderm) produces GDNF (glial cell line-derived neurotrophic factor), which binds to Ret/GFRalpha1 receptors on the Wolffian duct epithelium. This attracts the ureteric bud to grow out from the Wolffian duct and invade the mesenchyme. (2) Ureteric bud branching: Once in contact with the mesenchyme, the ureteric bud undergoes iterative branching morphogenesis (ultimately ~15 generations of branching). Branching is promoted by GDNF/Ret signaling and regulated by BMP, Wnt, and FGF signals from the surrounding mesenchyme. The branching pattern generates the collecting duct system and the renal pelvis/calyces. (3) Nephron induction: At each branch tip, the ureteric bud secretes Wnt9b and Wnt11, which induce adjacent metanephric mesenchyme cells to condense, undergo mesenchymal-to-epithelial transition (MET — the reverse of EMT), and form a renal vesicle. This vesicle elongates into a comma-shaped body, then an S-shaped body, and finally differentiates into a complete nephron (glomerulus, proximal tubule, loop of Henle, distal tubule) that connects to the ureteric bud-derived collecting duct. (4) Reciprocal: The interaction is truly reciprocal — mesenchyme induces bud branching (GDNF), and the bud induces nephron formation (Wnt). Neither tissue develops normally in isolation. (5) Transcription factors: Key TFs include Pax2/8 and WT1 in the mesenchyme (WT1 mutations cause Wilms tumor, a pediatric kidney cancer), and Hoxb7 in the ureteric bud.

questions.question: A researcher wants to test whether cell fate in the early mammalian embryo is determined by position (outside vs inside) rather than by lineage (inherited from a specific parent cell). Which experiment would best test this?
options: Count the number of cells at each developmental stage

Disaggregate an 8-cell embryo, reaggregate the cells in a new random arrangement, allow development to proceed, and demonstrate that cells adopt fates based on their new positions (outside cells become trophectoderm, inside cells become ICM) regardless of their original position in the embryo
Observe natural development without manipulation
Sequence the genome of individual blastomeres
questions.explanation: This experiment directly tests the inside-outside hypothesis of mammalian cell fate determination: (1) Experimental logic: If cell fate is determined by lineage (inherited determinants), then reassembling cells in new positions should not change their fate — they should develop according to their original position. If cell fate is determined by current position, cells should adopt new fates matching their new positions. (2) Procedure: (a) Dissociate an 8-cell embryo into individual blastomeres using calcium-free medium (to disrupt E-cadherin-mediated adhesion). (b) Reaggregate the cells in a random arrangement (or specifically place cells in new positions). (c) Culture to the blastocyst stage and assess lineage allocation using markers: Cdx2 for trophectoderm, Oct4/Nanog for ICM. (3) Expected result if position-dependent: Cells on the outside of the reaggregate adopt trophectoderm fate (Cdx2+), cells on the inside adopt ICM fate (Oct4+/Nanog+), regardless of their original position. This was indeed observed in classic experiments by Tarkowski and Wroblewska (1967) and confirmed with modern molecular markers. (4) Additional evidence: When two 8-cell embryos are combined (creating a chimeric 16-cell morula), cells adopt fates based on their position in the combined aggregate — both sets of cells contribute to both TE and ICM. This demonstrates regulative development and position-dependent fate specification. (5) Molecular mechanism: As discussed, the Hippo pathway reads cell polarity (outside vs inside position) and activates the appropriate transcriptional programs. (6) Caveats: While position is the primary determinant, recent studies show subtle biases — the first cleavage plane may influence the proportion of cells allocated to ICM vs TE, suggesting some very early asymmetries.

questions.question: Angiogenesis (formation of new blood vessels from existing ones) is critical during embryonic development and wound healing. What distinguishes angiogenesis from vasculogenesis?
options: Vasculogenesis is the de novo formation of blood vessels from angioblasts (mesodermal precursors) that coalesce into a primary vascular plexus, while angiogenesis is the sprouting of new vessels from pre-existing ones, driven by VEGF signaling that activates endothelial tip cells to extend filopodia and guide new sprouts toward hypoxic tissue
Vasculogenesis occurs only in adults while angiogenesis occurs only in embryos
Angiogenesis produces only lymphatic vessels while vasculogenesis produces blood vessels
Angiogenesis and vasculogenesis are identical processes
questions.explanation: Blood vessel formation involves two distinct but sequential processes: (1) Vasculogenesis (embryonic, de novo): During early embryogenesis, mesodermal cells differentiate into angioblasts (endothelial progenitor cells) under the influence of FGF and BMP signaling. Angioblasts express VEGFR2 (KDR/Flk1) and coalesce to form blood islands (aggregates of angioblasts surrounding hematopoietic precursors). These blood islands fuse to form a primary vascular plexus — a simple, honeycomb-like network of vessels. This occurs in the yolk sac (extraembryonic vasculogenesis) and within the embryo proper. (2) Angiogenesis (sprouting from existing vessels): The primary plexus is remodeled and expanded through angiogenesis — sprouting of new vessel branches from pre-existing vessels. The key driver is VEGF-A (vascular endothelial growth factor A), which is secreted by hypoxic tissues. VEGF binds VEGFR2 on endothelial cells, activating a tip cell that extends filopodia and guides the growing sprout. (3) Tip-stalk cell selection: Delta-Notch lateral inhibition selects tip vs stalk cells. VEGF induces Dll4 (Delta-like 4) in the tip cell; Dll4 activates Notch in adjacent cells, suppressing their VEGFR2 expression and making them stalk cells (which proliferate to extend the sprout but do not lead). (4) Clinical: Tumor angiogenesis (driven by tumor-secreted VEGF) is targeted by anti-angiogenic therapies (bevacizumab/Avastin, anti-VEGF antibody). VEGF knockout is embryonic lethal (even heterozygous). (5) Lymphangiogenesis: Lymphatic vessels develop from venous endothelium under Prox1 transcription factor control, using VEGF-C/VEGFR3 signaling.

questions.question: Teratology is the study of birth defects. What is the critical period concept, and why are the first 8 weeks of human gestation particularly sensitive to teratogens?
options: The critical period is when the fetus is largest and therefore most exposed to toxins
The critical period is the third trimester when organs are fully formed
There is no critical period — all stages of development are equally susceptible

The critical period is the time window during which an organ system is undergoing active morphogenesis and is most susceptible to teratogenic disruption — the first 8 weeks encompass organogenesis (formation of all major organ systems), making this the period of greatest vulnerability to structural birth defects
questions.explanation: The critical period concept is fundamental to teratology and reproductive toxicology: (1) Definition: The critical period for an organ is the developmental window during which that organ is undergoing active morphogenesis — cell proliferation, migration, differentiation, and pattern formation. During this window, the organ is exquisitely sensitive to disruption by teratogens (chemicals, radiation, infections, nutritional deficiencies). Before the critical period, the organ has not yet begun forming; after it, the major structures are established and less vulnerable. (2) Human timeline: Weeks 3-8 of gestation (embryonic period) encompass organogenesis — all major organ systems are established. The heart begins forming at week 3, limbs at weeks 4-8, face at weeks 5-8, and external genitalia at weeks 7-12. This is the period of maximum susceptibility to structural birth defects (malformations). (3) All-or-nothing period: Weeks 1-2 (pre-implantation) follow an 'all-or-nothing' rule — severe damage kills the embryo, while mild damage is repaired due to the regulative capacity of the early embryo. Few structural defects result from teratogen exposure during this period. (4) Fetal period: After week 8, organs continue to grow and mature but major structural patterns are established. Teratogen exposure during the fetal period causes functional defects (growth restriction, intellectual disability) rather than major structural malformations. (5) Organ-specific timing: Neural tube closure (weeks 3-4), heart septation (weeks 4-8), palate fusion (weeks 6-9), and limb development (weeks 4-8) each have distinct critical periods. Thalidomide, for example, causes limb defects (phocomelia) only when taken during days 20-36 post-fertilization, correlating precisely with the limb bud critical period.

questions.question: Somatic cell nuclear transfer (SCNT) was used to create Dolly the sheep. What key developmental biology principle did this experiment demonstrate?
options: That the nucleus of a differentiated adult somatic cell retains all the genetic information needed to direct development of an entire organism — proving that cell differentiation involves changes in gene expression rather than gene loss, and that the cytoplasm of an enucleated oocyte contains factors capable of epigenetically reprogramming a somatic nucleus to totipotency
That embryonic development requires only cytoplasm without any nuclear contribution
That adult somatic cells have irreversibly lost genetic information during differentiation
That mitochondrial DNA alone can direct embryonic development
questions.explanation: Dolly (born 1996, Campbell and Wilmut) was the first mammal cloned from an adult somatic cell and provided definitive proof of nuclear equivalence: (1) Experiment: The nucleus from a mammary gland epithelial cell of an adult Finn Dorset ewe was transferred into an enucleated (nucleus-removed) oocyte from a Scottish Blackface ewe. The reconstructed embryo was activated electrically, cultured to the blastocyst stage, and transferred to a surrogate mother. Dolly was genetically identical to the Finn Dorset mammary cell donor. (2) Nuclear equivalence: This proved that a fully differentiated adult cell nucleus retains the complete genome — no genes are permanently lost during differentiation (with minor exceptions like immunoglobulin gene rearrangement in lymphocytes and red blood cell enucleation). Cell specialization is achieved through differential gene expression (epigenetic regulation), not gene loss. (3) Reprogramming: The oocyte cytoplasm contains reprogramming factors that can reset the somatic nucleus's epigenetic state — removing differentiation-specific epigenetic marks (DNA methylation patterns, histone modifications) and re-establishing a totipotent state. This is conceptually related to iPSC reprogramming but achieved by oocyte factors rather than defined transcription factors. (4) Limitations: SCNT is extremely inefficient (Dolly was the only success from 277 attempts, <0.4% efficiency), and cloned animals often show abnormalities — aberrant DNA methylation, premature aging, telomere shortening, large offspring syndrome, and immune deficiencies. These reflect incomplete epigenetic reprogramming. (5) Historical context: Earlier nuclear transfer experiments in amphibians (Briggs and King, 1952; Gurdon, 1962) demonstrated nuclear equivalence with frog intestinal cells, earning Gurdon the 2012 Nobel Prize alongside Yamanaka.

questions.question: What is the role of the primitive streak in avian and mammalian gastrulation?
options: The primitive streak is a permanent structure that persists into adulthood

The primitive streak is a transient midline groove in the epiblast through which cells ingress via EMT to form mesoderm (moving laterally and anteriorly) and definitive endoderm (displacing the hypoblast), with Hensen's node at its anterior tip functioning as the organizer equivalent
The primitive streak forms only in the extraembryonic membranes
The primitive streak generates only ectodermal derivatives
questions.explanation: The primitive streak is the site of gastrulation in amniote embryos (birds, reptiles, mammals): (1) Formation: In the chick, the primitive streak forms as a thickening of the epiblast at the posterior marginal zone, then elongates anteriorly across the epiblast surface. In the mouse, it forms at the posterior end of the epiblast at E6.5. The streak is induced by Nodal and Wnt signaling. (2) EMT and ingression: Epiblast cells converge toward the streak from both sides, undergo EMT (losing E-cadherin, gaining N-cadherin, Snail/Slug activation), and ingress through the streak into the interior of the embryo. This is the primary mechanism of gastrulation in amniotes. (3) Germ layer formation: Cells that ingress through the anterior streak early form definitive endoderm (replacing the hypoblast/visceral endoderm). Cells that ingress later and through the more posterior streak form mesoderm — which migrates laterally between the epiblast and endoderm. Epiblast cells that do not ingress become ectoderm. (4) Hensen's node: The anterior tip of the primitive streak (Hensen's node in chick, the node in mouse) is the organizer equivalent of Spemann's organizer. It secretes BMP antagonists (Chordin, Noggin), Wnt antagonists (Cerberus, DKK1), and Nodal antagonists (Lefty), inducing neural tissue and organizing the body axes. Cells that pass through the node form the notochord (axial mesoderm). (5) Regression: As the embryo elongates, the streak shortens from anterior to posterior, eventually remaining only as the tail bud. Failure of streak regression causes sacrococcygeal teratoma. (6) Mammals: The process is essentially identical in mice and humans, though occurring in a cup-shaped (mouse) or flat disc (human, chick) geometry.

questions.question: What role does the extracellular matrix (ECM) play in embryonic cell migration?
options: ECM components are identical in all tissues and do not vary spatially

The ECM provides both structural substrates (fibronectin, laminin, collagen) for cell adhesion and migration via integrin receptors, and guidance cues — including permissive tracks that promote migration and inhibitory barriers (versican, tenascin) that restrict and channel migrating cells to specific pathways
ECM is a passive structural scaffold with no role in directing cell migration
ECM is found only in adult tissues and is absent during embryonic development
questions.explanation: The extracellular matrix plays essential, active roles in directing embryonic cell migration: (1) Migration substrate: Migrating cells require a physical substrate to adhere to and exert traction upon. Fibronectin is the primary migration substrate in the early embryo — it is deposited along migration pathways and provides adhesive contacts through RGD (Arg-Gly-Asp) motifs recognized by integrin receptors (alpha5-beta1 integrin) on migrating cells. Laminin serves a similar role in basement membrane-guided migration. (2) Integrin signaling: Integrins do not merely anchor cells — they activate intracellular signaling cascades (FAK, Src, Rac, Rho) that regulate cytoskeletal dynamics, cell polarity, and migration speed. Integrin-ECM engagement at focal adhesions provides traction force for movement. (3) Guidance cues: ECM molecules provide spatial information: (a) Permissive substrates (fibronectin, laminin) promote migration along specific tracks. For example, neural crest cells migrate along fibronectin-rich pathways. (b) Inhibitory barriers (versican, tenascin-C, chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans) prevent migration into certain territories. Neural crest cells are excluded from posterior somite halves by ephrin-B/EphB repulsion and versican. (4) Growth factor presentation: The ECM sequesters and presents growth factors (FGF, TGF-beta, BMP, Wnt) — heparan sulfate proteoglycans (perlecan, agrin) bind growth factors and create local signaling gradients. (5) Mechanical properties: ECM stiffness influences cell behavior through mechanotransduction. Cells sense ECM stiffness via integrin-cytoskeleton coupling and can migrate toward stiffer substrates (durotaxis). (6) Remodeling: Matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) cleave ECM components, enabling migration through dense matrices and releasing sequestered growth factors.

questions.question: Axis specification in the chick embryo begins before gastrulation through signals from the hypoblast and marginal zone. What signal determines the posterior end where the primitive streak will form?
options: Gravity determines which end becomes posterior in the chick embryo
Random cell death at one edge of the blastoderm determines polarity
BMP signaling from the anterior marginal zone specifies the posterior site

Wnt and Vg1/GDF1 signaling from the posterior marginal zone (Koller's sickle) induces Nodal expression, which drives primitive streak formation at the posterior end, while anterior signals (Cerberus, Lefty) from the hypoblast inhibit streak formation anteriorly
questions.explanation: Chick axis specification involves interplay between posterior inducing signals and anterior inhibitory signals: (1) Posterior marginal zone: Koller's sickle (a crescent-shaped thickening at the posterior edge of the area pellucida) is the site where the primitive streak will form. This region expresses Wnt8C, Vg1 (GDF1), and FGF, which together induce Nodal expression. Nodal (acting through Smad2/3 signaling) is the key driver of primitive streak and mesendoderm formation. (2) Anterior inhibition: The hypoblast (a thin layer of cells beneath the epiblast) secretes antagonists including Cerberus and Lefty that inhibit Nodal signaling anteriorly, restricting streak formation to the posterior. Rotation of the hypoblast repositions the streak — demonstrating that the hypoblast's inhibitory activity defines the anterior-posterior axis. (3) Gravity and pH: Before laying, rotation of the egg in the oviduct creates a pH gradient across the blastoderm (due to asymmetric albumin secretion) that influences posterior-anterior polarity. This means the A-P axis is influenced by the physical environment even before incubation begins. (4) Streak elongation: Once initiated, the streak extends anteriorly by addition of cells at its posterior end and convergence of epiblast cells toward the midline. The fully formed streak extends about 60% of the blastoderm diameter. (5) Single streak: The posterior marginal zone acts as a self-organizing center — if two posterior marginal zones are grafted onto opposite sides of a host, they inhibit each other through Lefty/Cerberus signals until one dominates, ensuring only one streak (and thus one body axis) forms.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about the Wnt signaling pathway in development:
(I) The canonical Wnt pathway stabilizes beta-catenin by inhibiting the APC/Axin/GSK-3 destruction complex, allowing beta-catenin to enter the nucleus and activate TCF/LEF target genes.
(II) The non-canonical Wnt/PCP (planar cell polarity) pathway controls convergent extension movements through RhoA/Rac1 GTPase signaling without involving beta-catenin stabilization.
(III) The Wnt/calcium pathway activates phospholipase C and PKC, influencing cell adhesion and migration.
(IV) Wnt signaling plays no role in stem cell maintenance or cancer and functions exclusively during embryonic development.
options: True
True
True
False
questions.explanation: Analysis of each statement: (I) TRUE — In the canonical Wnt pathway, Wnt ligands bind Frizzled (Fzd) receptor and LRP5/6 co-receptor, triggering Dishevelled (Dsh/Dvl) activation. Activated Dsh recruits Axin to the membrane, disrupting the beta-catenin destruction complex (APC/Axin/CK1/GSK-3beta). Without destruction complex activity, beta-catenin is not phosphorylated, escapes ubiquitination, accumulates in the cytoplasm, and translocates to the nucleus where it displaces Groucho co-repressor from TCF/LEF transcription factors and recruits co-activators (CBP, BCL9, Pygo) to activate Wnt target genes (c-Myc, Cyclin D1, Axin2). (II) TRUE — The non-canonical Wnt/PCP pathway signals through Wnt5a, Wnt11, and their receptors Fzd/Ror2/Ryk. Dishevelled activates small GTPases: RhoA (via DAAM1 formin) and Rac1. These reorganize the actin cytoskeleton, generating mediolateral cell polarity and driving convergent extension movements during gastrulation and neural tube closure. Core PCP proteins (Vangl2, Prickle, Celsr) establish planar polarity within epithelial sheets. (III) TRUE — The Wnt/calcium pathway, often triggered by Wnt5a/Fzd, activates heterotrimeric G proteins, phospholipase C (PLC), and inositol trisphosphate (IP3)-mediated calcium release. Elevated calcium activates CaMKII and PKC, which influence cell adhesion, migration, and gene expression. This pathway can antagonize canonical Wnt signaling. (IV) FALSE — Wnt signaling is critically important beyond embryonic development. In adults, canonical Wnt signaling maintains stem cell populations in the intestinal crypt (Lgr5+ stem cells), hair follicle bulge, and hematopoietic system. Aberrant Wnt activation is a major driver of cancer — APC loss-of-function mutations (constitutive Wnt signaling) cause ~80% of colorectal cancers. Wnt pathway components (Axin, beta-catenin, TCF) are mutated in various cancers.

questions.question: What is the community effect in developmental biology?
options: Individual cells always differentiate regardless of the number of neighboring cells
The community effect refers to interactions between different species' embryos
The community effect describes how all cells in an embryo differentiate simultaneously

The community effect is the phenomenon where cells require a minimum number of neighboring cells of the same type to maintain their differentiated state — first described by Gurdon for Xenopus muscle differentiation, where isolated mesoderm cells fail to express muscle genes but groups of cells above a threshold number successfully differentiate
questions.explanation: The community effect, discovered by John Gurdon, reveals that cell differentiation is not purely cell-autonomous: (1) Discovery: Gurdon (1988) found that single Xenopus mesoderm cells transplanted to the blastocoel cavity failed to maintain muscle gene expression (MyoD, actin), even though they were initially induced to become muscle. However, when groups of mesoderm cells (above ~100 cells) were transplanted, they successfully differentiated into muscle. (2) Mechanism: The community effect involves autocrine/paracrine signaling — cells secrete signals that reinforce their own and their neighbors' differentiation state. In a small group, these signals are diluted below the threshold needed for reinforcement. In a sufficiently large group, cells generate enough mutual reinforcement to maintain differentiation. (3) Molecular basis: In Xenopus muscle, the community effect involves FGF signaling — mesoderm cells secrete eFGF (embryonic FGF), which reinforces their own XMyoD expression through an autocrine loop. Below the threshold cell number, eFGF concentration is too low to maintain the positive feedback. (4) General principle: Community effects ensure that isolated cells accidentally placed in the wrong location do not inappropriately differentiate — a safety mechanism. They also sharpen tissue boundaries by requiring a minimum local density of committed cells. (5) Broader relevance: Community effects have been demonstrated in other contexts including neural induction, cartilage differentiation, and pancreatic beta-cell function (insulin secretion is enhanced when beta cells are in clusters vs isolated). In cancer, a 'community effect' may explain why minimum tumor cell numbers are needed for successful metastasis.

questions.question:
A researcher creates a series of chimeric embryos by combining different numbers of cells from two mouse strains (labeled with GFP vs RFP):

Chimera composition | ICM contribution (GFP:RFP) | TE contribution (GFP:RFP) | Development
16 GFP + 0 RFP | 100% GFP | 100% GFP | Normal
12 GFP + 4 RFP | 65% GFP, 35% RFP | 70% GFP, 30% RFP | Normal
8 GFP + 8 RFP | 48% GFP, 52% RFP | 50% GFP, 50% RFP | Normal
4 GFP + 12 RFP | 30% GFP, 70% RFP | 35% GFP, 65% RFP | Normal
0 GFP + 16 RFP | 100% RFP | 100% RFP | Normal

What do these data demonstrate about the early mammalian embryo?
options: Mammalian blastomeres are highly regulative — cells from both donor strains contribute proportionally to both ICM and TE regardless of their original position, demonstrating that early blastomeres are not committed to specific lineages and can adopt either ICM or TE fate based on their final position in the chimeric morula
Cell fate is fixed at the 2-cell stage and cannot be altered
Chimeric embryos always fail to develop normally
Only GFP cells can contribute to the ICM
questions.explanation: These chimera experiments are the definitive demonstration of regulative development in mammals: (1) Proportional contribution: In every chimera combination, both donor strains (GFP and RFP) contribute to both ICM and TE in roughly the same proportion as their overall representation. For example, in 8+8 chimeras, the ICM is approximately 50/50, as is the TE. This means cells from both sources can adopt either fate. (2) Regulative capacity: If cell fates were determined before aggregation (mosaic development), we would expect cells to maintain their original fates regardless of new context. Instead, cells adjust their fates based on their position in the chimeric morula — those ending up on the outside become TE, those inside become ICM. (3) Historical significance: Chimera experiments by Tarkowski (1961) and Mintz (1962) were foundational. They showed that even aggregates of cells from completely different embryos develop normally, with cells seamlessly integrating. Later, Gardner and colleagues showed that ICM cells from one embryo could contribute to all tissues of a chimeric adult. (4) Implications: This regulative capacity means: (a) cell fate is determined by position, not lineage; (b) early blastomeres are equivalent in developmental potential; (c) identical twinning (natural splitting of the morula/ICM) produces complete individuals; (d) biopsy of blastomeres for preimplantation genetic testing does not compromise embryo viability. (5) Limits: Regulative capacity decreases with developmental stage. By the late blastocyst, ICM and TE cells have become committed (Cdx2 vs Oct4 mutual repression), and their fates cannot be easily reversed.

questions.question: During Drosophila eye development, the R7 photoreceptor cell is specified through an inductive signal from the R8 cell. Which signaling pathway mediates this specification?
options: Hedgehog signaling from posterior to anterior in the eye disc
Wnt signaling from the morphogenetic furrow

The Boss (Bride of Sevenless) ligand on R8 activates the Sevenless receptor tyrosine kinase on the R7 precursor cell, triggering the Ras-MAPK signaling cascade that specifies R7 fate — this was the genetic system that elucidated the RTK-Ras-MAPK pathway
Notch-Delta signaling from R8 to R7
questions.explanation: The specification of R7 in the Drosophila eye is a landmark story in signal transduction: (1) The system: The Drosophila compound eye consists of approximately 800 ommatidia, each containing 8 photoreceptor neurons (R1-R8). R7 is the UV-sensitive photoreceptor. Its specification depends on a contact-dependent inductive signal from the neighboring R8 cell. (2) Boss-Sevenless signaling: R8 expresses Boss (Bride of Sevenless), a transmembrane ligand. Boss activates Sevenless (Sev), a receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) expressed on the surface of the R7 precursor cell. This is a contact-dependent (juxtacrine) signaling event. (3) RTK-Ras-MAPK cascade: Activated Sevenless autophosphorylates, recruiting the adaptor protein Drk (Grb2 homolog) via its SH2 domain. Drk recruits Sos (a guanine nucleotide exchange factor) which activates Ras (converting Ras-GDP to Ras-GTP). Active Ras initiates the MAPK cascade: Raf → MEK → MAPK (rolled in Drosophila). MAPK phosphorylates transcription factors (Pointed, Yan) that activate R7-specific gene expression. (4) Historical significance: Genetic screens for sevenless pathway mutants in Drosophila (by Rubin, Simon, and others) identified most components of the RTK-Ras-MAPK pathway before it was known to be a universal growth factor signaling pathway in mammals. The same pathway (EGF/PDGF/FGF → Ras → Raf → MEK → ERK) controls cell proliferation, differentiation, and survival in all metazoans. Ras mutations (KRAS, HRAS, NRAS) are found in ~30% of human cancers. (5) Without Boss or Sevenless, the R7 precursor defaults to a cone cell fate instead of R7, demonstrating the inductive signal is necessary for R7 specification.

questions.question: What are organoids, and what developmental principles do they exploit?
options: Organoids are fully formed organs grown in culture from single cells
Organoids are computer models that simulate organ development

Organoids are three-dimensional tissue structures grown from stem cells (ESCs, iPSCs, or adult tissue stem cells) in vitro that self-organize into miniature organ-like structures recapitulating key features of tissue architecture and function, exploiting the intrinsic self-organizing capacity of cells driven by the same signaling pathways (Wnt, BMP, FGF, Notch) that pattern organs in vivo
Organoids require transplantation into an animal host to develop structure
questions.explanation: Organoids represent a revolution in developmental biology and disease modeling: (1) Definition: Organoids are three-dimensional multicellular structures that self-organize from stem cells in culture, forming miniature versions of organs with tissue architecture, multiple cell types, and some organ-specific functions. They are grown in extracellular matrix (typically Matrigel) supplemented with growth factors that recapitulate developmental signaling. (2) Key examples: (a) Intestinal organoids (Clevers lab, 2009): Lgr5+ intestinal stem cells in Matrigel with R-spondin (Wnt agonist), Noggin (BMP inhibitor), and EGF self-organize into crypt-villus structures with all intestinal cell types (enterocytes, goblet cells, Paneth cells, enteroendocrine cells); (b) Brain organoids (Lancaster and Knoblich, 2013): iPSC-derived neural organoids form layered cortical structures with progenitor zones and neuronal layers; (c) Kidney, liver, lung, retinal, and gastric organoids have all been generated. (3) Developmental principles: Organoids work because stem cells retain intrinsic developmental programs — when provided with appropriate signals, they self-organize using the same morphogen gradients, lateral inhibition, and tissue mechanics that operate in vivo. Wnt gradients establish stem cell niches, BMP inhibition maintains progenitor zones, Notch mediates lateral inhibition for cell type diversification. (4) Applications: Disease modeling (cystic fibrosis, cancer), drug screening, personalized medicine, gene editing studies, and understanding organ development. Patient-derived tumor organoids can predict drug responses. (5) Limitations: Organoids lack vasculature, immune cells, and nervous system innervation; they are limited in size by diffusion of oxygen and nutrients; and they do not perfectly recapitulate organ-level organization.

questions.question: A researcher wants to determine whether a specific morphogen (Morphogen X) acts as a true morphogen — specifying multiple cell fates at different concentrations — in the developing wing disc of Drosophila. Which experimental strategy would be most rigorous?
options: Create clones of cells that express a constitutively active form of Morphogen X's receptor at different levels (using different promoter strengths), demonstrating that increasing levels of pathway activation cell-autonomously specify different cell fates in a position-independent manner, then show that a uniform field of Morphogen X at different concentrations produces distinct cell types at each concentration
Simply overexpress Morphogen X everywhere and observe the result
Measure Morphogen X protein levels without functional studies
Knock out Morphogen X and observe which structures are missing
questions.explanation: Proving that a signal acts as a true morphogen (rather than simply permissive for a single fate) requires demonstrating concentration-dependent, cell-autonomous fate specification: (1) True morphogen criteria (Wolpert's definition): A morphogen must (a) form a concentration gradient in a developing field, (b) directly specify at least two different cell fates at different threshold concentrations, and (c) act directly on target cells (not through a relay of secondary signals). (2) Constitutive receptor activation: By creating clones expressing the receptor at defined levels (mimicking different morphogen concentrations), the researcher tests whether pathway activity level alone determines cell fate, independent of position. If cells expressing high receptor activity adopt fate A, medium activity adopt fate B, and low activity adopt fate C — regardless of where in the tissue the clones are located — this demonstrates concentration-dependent, position-independent fate specification. (3) Concentration series: Exposing a uniform field of competent cells (e.g., wing disc cells in culture) to different defined concentrations of Morphogen X and demonstrating distinct, concentration-specific outcomes provides complementary evidence. (4) Classic examples: Dpp (BMP homolog) in the Drosophila wing disc meets all morphogen criteria — it forms a gradient from the A-P compartment boundary, directly activates target genes (spalt, omb) at different threshold concentrations, and constitutive Dpp pathway activation at different levels specifies different cell fates cell-autonomously. (5) Controls: Loss-of-function (receptor knockout clones) should show loss of all morphogen-dependent fates. Ectopic expression at specific levels should induce specific fates ectopically.

questions.question: What is the function of the sperm centrosome (centriole) after fertilization in most animals?
options: The sperm centrosome is degraded immediately after sperm-egg fusion
Both maternal and paternal centrosomes organize the first mitotic spindle equally

The sperm-derived centriole serves as the organizing center for the first mitotic spindle of the zygote, since the oocyte's centrioles were eliminated during oogenesis — the sperm thus provides both the paternal genome and the centrosome required for cell division
The sperm centrosome is only needed for sperm flagellar movement and has no post-fertilization role
questions.explanation: The sperm centrosome contribution is essential for the first zygotic cell division in most animals: (1) Oocyte centriole loss: During oogenesis in most animal species (mammals, sea urchins, Drosophila), the oocyte's centrioles are eliminated or degraded. The mature oocyte therefore lacks functional centrioles and centrosomes. Meiotic spindles in the oocyte are assembled without centrioles (acentrosomal spindle assembly using RanGTP-dependent mechanisms). (2) Sperm centriole: The sperm brings two centrioles — the proximal centriole (at the base of the nucleus, which it retains) and the distal centriole (which becomes modified as the basal body of the flagellum). After sperm-egg fusion, the sperm axoneme and mitochondria are typically degraded, but the proximal centriole is retained. (3) Zygotic centrosome: The sperm-derived centriole recruits maternal pericentriolar material (PCM, including gamma-tubulin ring complexes, pericentrin) from the egg cytoplasm. It duplicates to form two centrosomes, which then nucleate the astral microtubules that form the mitotic spindle for the first zygotic division. (4) Pronuclear migration: Before the first division, the sperm centrosome also organizes the microtubule aster that draws the two pronuclei (male and female) together for syngamy. (5) Exceptions: In mice, both sperm centrioles are degraded during spermiogenesis, and the first mitotic spindle is assembled acentrosomally using RanGTP-dependent mechanisms (similar to meiotic spindles). This is an exception rather than the rule. (6) Clinical: Defective sperm centrioles can cause fertilization failure or abnormal first cleavage, contributing to some cases of ICSI failure and early embryonic arrest.

questions.question: Xenopus animal cap explants have been instrumental in understanding inductive signaling. What makes the animal cap a valuable experimental system?
options: The animal cap (the ectodermal tissue at the animal pole of the blastula) is a naive, multipotent tissue that defaults to epidermis but can be induced to form neural tissue (by BMP inhibition), mesoderm (by Activin/Nodal), or endoderm (by high Activin) — providing a blank canvas for testing inductive signals
The animal cap produces all three germ layers autonomously
Animal cap cells are already fully differentiated and cannot respond to signals
Animal cap tissue is unique to Xenopus and does not exist in other species
questions.explanation: The Xenopus animal cap is one of the most powerful tools in experimental embryology: (1) Properties: The animal cap comprises the uppermost (animal pole) region of the blastula, consisting of approximately 1000 ectodermal cells. When explanted (surgically removed) and cultured in isolation, it defaults to forming epidermis (atypical epidermis, specifically ciliated epidermal balls). This makes it a naive, responsive tissue — a 'blank canvas' that can be redirected to various fates by appropriate signals. (2) Neural induction: When animal cap cells are treated with BMP antagonists (Noggin, Chordin) or dissociated (which dilutes endogenous BMP signaling), they adopt neural fate instead of epidermis. This was the key experiment supporting the 'default model' of neural induction — ectoderm defaults to neural fate in the absence of BMP signaling. (3) Mesoderm induction: Animal cap cells treated with Activin (a Nodal family member) at low-to-moderate concentrations form mesoderm (muscle, notochord). Different Activin concentrations induce different mesodermal subtypes — low Activin: ventral mesoderm (blood), medium Activin: muscle, high Activin: notochord and endoderm. This demonstrated the concentration-dependent (morphogen) activity of TGF-beta family ligands. (4) Competence: The animal cap is 'competent' to respond to mesoderm inducers only during a specific developmental window (mid-blastula to early gastrula). Outside this window, competence is lost. (5) Modern applications: Animal caps are used in combination with defined recombinant proteins or injected mRNAs to dissect signaling pathway interactions, test epistatic relationships, and identify downstream target genes using transcriptomic approaches.

questions.question: What is the role of gap junctions during embryonic development?
options: Gap junctions are present only in adult tissues and absent during development
Gap junctions provide structural support like rivets between cells
Gap junctions transport proteins and mRNAs between cells

Gap junctions are channels formed by connexin proteins that allow direct cytoplasmic communication between adjacent cells, permitting passage of small molecules (ions, metabolites, second messengers like cAMP and IP3) up to ~1 kDa, enabling coordinated signaling and metabolic coupling during compaction, implantation, and tissue patterning
questions.explanation: Gap junctions play multiple essential roles in embryonic development: (1) Structure: Each gap junction channel is composed of two hemichannels (connexons), one from each cell. Each connexon consists of six connexin (Cx) protein subunits arranged around a central pore. The pore diameter (~1.5 nm) allows passage of molecules up to approximately 1 kDa — including ions (Ca2+, K+), metabolites (glucose, amino acids), and second messengers (cAMP, cGMP, IP3). Proteins and nucleic acids cannot pass. (2) Developmental roles: (a) Compaction: Gap junctional communication (GJC) begins at the 8-cell stage in mouse embryos (mediated by Cx43/GJA1) and is essential for compaction. (b) Oocyte maturation: Gap junctions between granulosa cells and the oocyte (Cx37/GJA4) transfer cGMP and cAMP that maintain meiotic arrest; LH surge closes these junctions to trigger meiosis resumption. (c) Left-right asymmetry: Cx43 gap junctions are involved in the transfer of serotonin and other small molecules that contribute to L-R axis establishment in some species. (d) Heart development: Cx43, Cx40, and Cx45 are essential for cardiac conduction. Cx43 knockout mice die at birth from cardiac malformations. (e) Neural tube closure: Gap junctional communication coordinates the epithelial movements during neurulation. (3) Patterning: Gap junctions enable 'community effects' by synchronizing signaling states among groups of cells. The passage of IP3 can propagate calcium waves across cell groups, coordinating responses to inductive signals. (4) Disease: Mutations in connexin genes cause diverse developmental disorders — Cx43 mutations cause oculodentodigital dysplasia, Cx26 mutations cause deafness, and Cx32 mutations cause Charcot-Marie-Tooth neuropathy.

questions.question:
A researcher studies the effect of retinoic acid (RA) concentration on the differentiation of embryonic stem cells in culture:

RA concentration (nM) | Cell type generated | Key markers | Percentage
0 | Undifferentiated ESCs | Oct4+, Nanog+, Sox2+ | 95%
10 | Neural progenitors (anterior) | Sox1+, Pax6+, Otx2+ | 60%
100 | Neural progenitors (posterior/hindbrain) | Hoxb1+, Hoxb4+, Krox20+ | 55%
1000 | Mesoderm/endoderm | Brachyury+, Gata4+ | 45%
10000 | Apoptosis + mesoderm | Cleaved caspase-3+, FLK1+ | 70% dead

What does this reveal about RA's role in differentiation?
options: All RA concentrations produce identical cell types
RA has no effect on stem cell differentiation at any concentration

RA acts as a concentration-dependent differentiation signal: low RA promotes anterior neural identity, moderate RA promotes posterior/hindbrain neural identity (consistent with its caudalizing role in vivo), high RA promotes mesoderm/endoderm, and very high RA is cytotoxic — demonstrating that RA is a morphogen-like signal whose concentration determines cell fate outcomes
RA maintains pluripotency at all concentrations
questions.explanation: The data demonstrate retinoic acid's concentration-dependent effects on cell fate: (1) RA as a caudalizing agent: In vivo, RA is a major posteriorizing (caudalizing) signal in the vertebrate embryo. It is synthesized by Raldh2 (retinaldehyde dehydrogenase 2) in the somites and lateral plate mesoderm, and is degraded by Cyp26 enzymes in the anterior. This creates a posterior-high, anterior-low RA gradient. (2) Low RA (10 nM): Promotes neural differentiation with anterior (forebrain/midbrain) identity — consistent with the default model where neural fate is the default state and low RA levels specify anterior neural character (Pax6+, Otx2+ are anterior neural markers). (3) Moderate RA (100 nM): Shifts neural fate toward posterior (hindbrain) identity. Hoxb1 and Hoxb4 are hindbrain Hox genes activated by RA (via RA response elements, RAREs, in their regulatory regions). Krox20 marks rhombomeres 3 and 5. This reflects RA's in vivo role in specifying hindbrain segment identities. (4) High RA (1000 nM): At supraphysiological concentrations, RA can induce non-neural fates including mesoderm (Brachyury) and endoderm (Gata4). This is consistent with RA's ability to activate multiple downstream pathways at different thresholds. (5) Toxic levels (10000 nM): Very high RA causes apoptosis, reflecting teratogenic effects. RA teratogenicity (e.g., isotretinoin/Accutane birth defects) results from disruption of morphogen gradients. (6) Mechanism: RA binds nuclear receptors (RARalpha/beta/gamma, which heterodimerize with RXR), directly regulating transcription of target genes. Different RA concentrations activate different gene sets based on promoter sensitivity (RARE affinity and number).

questions.question: What is transdetermination in Drosophila imaginal disc development?
options: The normal differentiation of an imaginal disc into its specified adult structure

The rare switching of one imaginal disc's determined state to that of another disc type — for example, a leg disc fragment generating wing tissue upon serial transplantation — demonstrating that determined states, while normally stable, are not irreversible and can switch to closely related alternative fates through changes in selector gene expression
The initial specification of imaginal disc identity during embryogenesis
The death of imaginal disc cells during metamorphosis
questions.explanation: Transdetermination reveals important principles about the stability and flexibility of determined states: (1) Imaginal discs: In Drosophila larvae, groups of cells called imaginal discs are set aside for adult structures. Each disc is 'determined' — committed to forming a specific adult structure (leg, wing, eye, antenna, etc.) — long before it actually differentiates. Determination is maintained through many cell divisions during larval growth. (2) Discovery: Hadorn (1968) discovered transdetermination by serially transplanting fragments of imaginal discs into the abdomens of adult flies (which support disc growth but not differentiation). After many rounds of transplantation and regeneration, rare disc fragments switched their determined state — for example, a leg disc fragment began generating wing tissue, or an antenna disc fragment produced leg structures. (3) Characteristics: (a) Transdetermination occurs at low frequency (~1-5% of disc fragments per transplant generation); (b) It follows specific rules — certain switches are more common than others (leg→wing is common, wing→leg is rare), suggesting a hierarchy of determined states; (c) Switches often involve closely related selector gene states (Antennapedia → wing via Vestigial activation); (d) Wnt/Wingless signaling promotes transdetermination frequency. (4) Molecular basis: Transdetermination involves changes in selector gene expression — for example, leg-to-wing switch involves downregulation of the leg selector gene (Distalless) and upregulation of the wing selector gene (Vestigial). This likely involves epigenetic switches at Polycomb/Trithorax-regulated loci. (5) Significance: Transdetermination shows that determination is maintained by ongoing regulatory circuits (not permanent DNA changes) and can be disrupted — foreshadowing modern cellular reprogramming (iPSCs, transdifferentiation).

questions.question: Somites differentiate into distinct regions under the influence of signals from surrounding tissues. What determines whether a somite cell becomes sclerotome, dermomyotome, or myotome?
options: Somite fate is determined entirely by maternal mRNAs deposited in the egg
All somite cells differentiate into muscle only

Shh from the notochord and floor plate induces ventromedial cells to become sclerotome (Pax1+, future vertebrae/ribs); Wnt from the dorsal neural tube and surface ectoderm induces dorsolateral cells to become dermomyotome (Pax3/7+, future dermis and muscle); and BMP from the lateral plate mesoderm influences lateral somite fate
All somite cells are identical and their fate is determined randomly
questions.explanation: Somite compartmentalization is driven by signals from surrounding tissues, providing a textbook example of embryonic induction: (1) Sclerotome (ventromedial): Sonic hedgehog (Shh) secreted from the notochord and floor plate induces the ventromedial portion of the somite to become sclerotome. Shh activates Pax1 expression and represses Pax3/7 in these cells. Sclerotome cells undergo EMT (losing N-cadherin, gaining mesenchymal markers), migrate medially around the neural tube and notochord, and eventually differentiate into vertebrae (via endochondral ossification) and ribs. Noggin from the notochord (BMP antagonist) cooperates with Shh. (2) Dermomyotome (dorsolateral): Wnt1/Wnt3a from the dorsal neural tube and Wnt7a from the surface ectoderm maintain the dorsal somite as dermomyotome, expressing Pax3 and Pax7. The dermomyotome has two fates: (a) its central region (dermatome) spreads beneath the ectoderm to form the dermis of the back; (b) its lips delaminate cells that migrate beneath the dermomyotome to form the myotome — the muscle precursor layer. (3) Myotome: Cells from the four lips of the dermomyotome (particularly medial and lateral lips) detach and form the myotome between the dermomyotome and sclerotome. Myf5 and MyoD (myogenic regulatory factors, MRFs) are activated in these cells, committing them to skeletal muscle fate. Wnt and Shh signals converge to activate MRFs. (4) BMP from lateral plate mesoderm: BMP4 from the adjacent lateral plate mesoderm promotes lateral dermomyotome fate and limb muscle precursor specification (Pax3+ cells that migrate into the limb bud). (5) Integration: The combination of Shh (ventral), Wnt (dorsal), and BMP (lateral) signals creates a three-dimensional fate map within each somite.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about X-chromosome inactivation (XCI) in mammalian females:
(I) XCI ensures dosage compensation between XX females and XY males by transcriptionally silencing one X chromosome in each female somatic cell.
(II) XCI is initiated by the long non-coding RNA Xist, which coats the future inactive X in cis, recruiting Polycomb repressive complexes and other silencing factors.
(III) The choice of which X to inactivate is random in the epiblast but determined (paternal X always inactivated) in mouse extraembryonic tissues.
(IV) X-chromosome inactivation is fully reversible in all adult somatic cells without any intervention.
options: True
True
True
False
questions.explanation: Analysis of each statement: (I) TRUE — X-chromosome inactivation (Lyon hypothesis, 1961) is the mammalian dosage compensation mechanism. One X chromosome is transcriptionally silenced in each female somatic cell early in development, equalizing X-linked gene dosage between XX females and XY males. The inactive X (Xi) is visible as the Barr body at the nuclear periphery. About 15-25% of X-linked genes escape inactivation and are expressed from both chromosomes. (II) TRUE — Xist (X-inactive specific transcript) is a 17-kb lncRNA transcribed from the X-inactivation center (Xic). Xist RNA spreads in cis along the future inactive X, coating it. Xist recruits: (a) SPEN/SHARP, which in turn recruits the NCoR-HDAC3 histone deacetylase complex for gene silencing; (b) PRC2 (which deposits H3K27me3); (c) PRC1 (which deposits H2AK119ub). Additional silencing mechanisms include DNA methylation of CpG islands (by DNMT3B), histone H4K20me1, and macroH2A histone variant incorporation. Xist deletion prevents XCI initiation. (III) TRUE — In mice, there are two forms of XCI: imprinted XCI (in the trophectoderm and primitive endoderm — always the paternal X is inactivated, regulated by the paternal-specific Xist activation and maternal-specific Tsix antisense RNA) and random XCI (in the epiblast/embryo proper — either X can be inactivated, with the choice being stochastic). Humans appear to have only random XCI (no imprinted XCI). (IV) FALSE — XCI is extremely stable in somatic cells and is NOT readily reversible. The multiple layers of silencing (Xist coating, Polycomb marks, DNA methylation, late replication timing, nuclear peripheral localization) make the inactive state highly stable through mitotic cell divisions. XCI is reversed only in very specific contexts: in primordial germ cells (X-reactivation occurs during epigenetic reprogramming at E11.5-13.5 in mouse) and during iPSC reprogramming. Spontaneous X-reactivation in somatic cells is associated with cancer.

questions.question: Gastrulation in sea urchins involves invagination of the vegetal plate. What is the role of filopodia extended by secondary mesenchyme cells during archenteron elongation?
options: Secondary mesenchyme cells at the tip of the elongating archenteron extend long filopodia that contact the inner surface of the blastocoel roof (animal pole), providing traction that pulls the archenteron across the blastocoel through a process of filopodial attachment and contraction, complementing convergent extension of the archenteron wall
Filopodia have no role in archenteron elongation
Filopodia are extended from the animal pole toward the vegetal plate
Filopodia push the archenteron away from the animal pole
questions.explanation: Archenteron elongation in sea urchins involves multiple complementary mechanisms: (1) Primary invagination: The initial inward buckling of the vegetal plate (forming the beginning of the archenteron) is driven by apical constriction of vegetal cells (bottle cells) and changes in extracellular matrix. This produces a short, stubby invagination extending approximately one-third of the way across the blastocoel. (2) Secondary invagination — convergent extension: The archenteron then elongates dramatically through convergent extension — cells in the archenteron wall rearrange by intercalating along the long axis, causing the tube to narrow and lengthen. This is analogous to convergent extension during vertebrate gastrulation. (3) Filopodial traction: Secondary mesenchyme cells (SMCs) at the leading tip of the archenteron extend long, dynamic filopodia (up to 80 micrometers) that explore the blastocoel cavity. When filopodia contact the inner surface of the animal pole (blastocoel roof), they attach and generate contractile force (using actin-myosin) that pulls the archenteron tip toward the animal pole. (4) Evidence: Laser ablation of SMC filopodia delays (but does not completely prevent) archenteron elongation, demonstrating that filopodial traction is one of multiple mechanisms. When the animal pole ectoderm is removed, filopodia fail to find attachment sites and archenteron elongation is impaired. (5) Target recognition: SMC filopodia show preferential attachment to a specific region of the animal pole — near the future mouth (stomodeum) — suggesting the target tissue provides guidance cues. (6) Mouth formation: After the archenteron reaches the animal pole, it fuses with the ectoderm at the oral side to form the mouth (deuterostome pattern — blastopore becomes anus, mouth is a secondary opening).
