questions.question: Asymmetric cell division is a fundamental mechanism for generating cellular diversity. What molecular machinery ensures that cell fate determinants are unequally distributed to the two daughter cells during neuroblast division in Drosophila?
options: Cell fate is determined after division by random external signals

The Par complex (Par3/Bazooka-Par6-aPKC) localizes to the apical cortex of the neuroblast, while cell fate determinants (Numb, Prospero, Miranda, Brat) are localized to the basal cortex by the adaptor proteins Miranda and Partner of Numb — upon division along the apical-basal axis, the apical daughter retains stem cell identity while the basal daughter (inheriting Numb and Prospero) differentiates
Both daughter cells receive equal determinants and differentiate identically
Only the mitotic spindle orientation matters; no determinants are asymmetrically distributed
questions.explanation: Drosophila neuroblast division is the paradigm for asymmetric cell division: (1) Neuroblast identity: Neuroblasts are neural stem cells that divide asymmetrically to produce a large apical daughter (renewed neuroblast) and a small basal daughter (ganglion mother cell, GMC, which divides once more to produce two neurons or glia). (2) Apical complex: The Par complex (Bazooka/Par3, Par6, aPKC) localizes to the apical cortex during late interphase. aPKC phosphorylates and excludes basal determinants from the apical domain. The apical complex also recruits Inscuteable and Pins/LGN/Mud, which orient the mitotic spindle along the apical-basal axis to ensure correct segregation. (3) Basal determinants: (a) Numb (Notch signaling inhibitor) — localizes to the basal crescent via its adaptor Partner of Numb (Pon). In the GMC, Numb inhibits Notch, preventing self-renewal and promoting differentiation. (b) Prospero (homeodomain transcription factor) — localized basally by the adaptor protein Miranda. In the GMC, Prospero enters the nucleus and activates differentiation genes while repressing cell cycle genes. (c) Brain tumor (Brat) — a translational repressor also localized by Miranda, promoting differentiation. (4) Spindle orientation: The Inscuteable-Pins-Mud complex connects the apical Par complex to astral microtubules via dynein, orienting the spindle perpendicular to the epithelium and parallel to the apical-basal axis. This ensures that division produces one apical daughter (inheriting Par complex, maintaining stem cell state) and one basal daughter (inheriting Numb/Prospero/Brat, committing to differentiation). (5) Cancer: Loss of Numb, Prospero, or Brat causes symmetric divisions producing two neuroblasts, leading to brain tumors — directly linking asymmetric division defects to tumorigenesis.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about epigenetic reprogramming during mammalian development:
(I) After fertilization, both the maternal and paternal genomes undergo extensive DNA demethylation, but the paternal genome is demethylated more rapidly through an active TET3-mediated oxidation mechanism.
(II) Imprinted genes escape the global wave of demethylation and maintain parent-of-origin-specific methylation marks throughout preimplantation development.
(III) De novo methylation by DNMT3A and DNMT3B re-establishes DNA methylation patterns during post-implantation development.
(IV) Histone modifications play no role in epigenetic reprogramming; only DNA methylation matters.
options: FTTT
TTFT
TFTT
TTTF
questions.explanation: Epigenetic reprogramming is essential for totipotency and proper development: (1) Statement I is TRUE: After fertilization, the paternal genome undergoes rapid active demethylation. TET3 (Ten-Eleven Translocation 3), a dioxygenase provided by the oocyte, oxidizes 5-methylcytosine (5mC) to 5-hydroxymethylcytosine (5hmC) and further oxidized derivatives on the paternal pronucleus. This is visible as loss of 5mC immunostaining in the paternal pronucleus within hours of fertilization. The maternal genome is demethylated more slowly through a replication-dependent (passive) mechanism, as DNMT1 (the maintenance methyltransferase) is excluded from the nucleus during early cleavages. (2) Statement II is TRUE: Imprinted genes (approximately 100-150 in mice) maintain their parent-of-origin methylation marks through preimplantation development. This is protected by DPPA3/Stella (PGC7), which binds H3K9me2-marked chromatin and protects maternal imprints from TET3-mediated oxidation, and by ZFP57/KAP1 (TRIM28), which recognizes methylated imprinting control regions and recruits DNMT1 to maintain methylation. (3) Statement III is TRUE: After implantation (around E3.5-E6.5 in mouse), the genome undergoes de novo methylation. DNMT3A and DNMT3B, along with cofactor DNMT3L, establish new methylation patterns. DNMT3B is primarily active in the embryo proper (epiblast), while DNMT3A methylates both embryonic and extraembryonic tissues. This de novo methylation establishes tissue-specific gene expression patterns. (4) Statement IV is FALSE: Histone modifications are critical for epigenetic reprogramming. Broad H3K4me3 and H3K27me3 domains are reorganized during preimplantation development. H3K9me3 and H3K27me3 (deposited by PRC2) help maintain gene silencing. The sperm genome carries bivalent chromatin marks (H3K4me3 + H3K27me3) at developmental gene promoters, poising them for later activation or silencing. Protamine-to-histone exchange in the paternal genome after fertilization is itself a major chromatin reprogramming event.

questions.question:
Researchers investigating cell fate specification performed single-cell RNA sequencing on mouse embryos at multiple developmental stages. The data shows:

Stage | Cell population | Key transcription factors | Cell count
E3.5 | Inner cell mass | Oct4+, Nanog+, Sox2+ | 12-15 cells
E3.5 | Trophectoderm | Cdx2+, Eomes+ | 40-60 cells
E4.5 | Epiblast | Oct4+, Nanog+, Fgf4+ | 8-10 cells
E4.5 | Primitive endoderm | Gata6+, Sox17+, Pdgfra+ | 8-10 cells
E4.5 | Trophectoderm | Cdx2+, Elf5+ | 60-80 cells

Which interpretation of the data is most accurate?
options: The data demonstrates the progressive lineage segregation model where the first binary decision (ICM vs TE at E3.5) is governed by Hippo signaling and position-dependent Cdx2/Oct4 mutual antagonism, followed by a second decision within the ICM (epiblast vs primitive endoderm at E4.5) driven by FGF4/FGFR2 signaling where initially salt-and-pepper distributed Nanog+ and Gata6+ cells sort into distinct layers
Primitive endoderm cells derive from the trophectoderm lineage
All cells maintain identical transcription factor profiles throughout development
Cell fate is determined entirely by cell size at the 8-cell stage
questions.explanation: This data illustrates the two sequential lineage segregation events in preimplantation mouse development: (1) First lineage decision (E3.0-E3.5): At the 16-32 cell stage (morula to blastocyst), outside cells become trophectoderm (TE) and inside cells become inner cell mass (ICM). This is regulated by the Hippo signaling pathway — outside cells experience low cell-cell contact, leading to nuclear YAP/TAZ which activates TEAD4 transcription factor. TEAD4 drives Cdx2 expression, which suppresses Oct4 and promotes TE identity. Inside cells have active Hippo signaling (high cell contact), leading to cytoplasmic YAP sequestration, no TEAD4 activity, and maintenance of Oct4/Nanog/Sox2 (pluripotency). CDX2 and OCT4 are mutually antagonistic. (2) Second lineage decision (E3.5-E4.5): Within the ICM, cells segregate into epiblast (which forms the embryo proper) and primitive endoderm (PrE, which forms the yolk sac endoderm). Initially, ICM cells co-express both Nanog and Gata6 in a salt-and-pepper pattern. FGF4 (produced by Nanog-high cells) signals through FGFR2 (on neighboring cells) to activate the Ras-MAPK pathway, promoting Gata6 and suppressing Nanog. This creates a bistable switch — cells commit to either Nanog+/Gata6- (epiblast) or Nanog-/Gata6+ (PrE). (3) Sorting: After specification, PrE cells sort to the blastocoelic surface of the ICM (forming a single epithelial layer), while epiblast cells remain internal. PrE cells that fail to reach the surface undergo apoptosis. (4) Experimental validation: Treating embryos with exogenous FGF4 converts all ICM cells to PrE (Gata6+), while FGFR/MEK inhibitors convert all to epiblast (Nanog+), demonstrating the FGF4-dependent mechanism. (5) The cell counts in the data reflect the normal proliferation and specification timeline of mouse preimplantation development.

questions.question: Compaction in the mouse embryo occurs at the 8-cell stage and is essential for the first lineage decision. What molecular mechanism drives compaction?
options: Only gap junction communication between blastomeres causes compaction
Compaction is a passive process requiring no molecular machinery
Compaction is driven by integrin-mediated attachment to a surrounding extracellular matrix

E-cadherin (encoded by Cdh1) mediates calcium-dependent cell-cell adhesion, while the Par-aPKC polarity complex establishes apical-basal polarity in outer cells — together, these processes increase cell-cell contact, flatten outer cells against inner cells, and create the inside-outside asymmetry necessary for trophectoderm versus ICM specification
questions.explanation: Compaction is a critical morphogenetic event in early mammalian development: (1) Timing: At the 8-cell stage, blastomeres undergo a dramatic change in morphology — they flatten against each other, maximize cell-cell contact, and the embryo transitions from a loose cluster of round cells to a tightly packed morula with a smooth outer surface. (2) E-cadherin: The primary adhesion molecule driving compaction is E-cadherin (CDH1). E-cadherin forms calcium-dependent homophilic interactions between adjacent cell surfaces. Before compaction, E-cadherin is present but not concentrated at cell-cell contacts. At the 8-cell stage, E-cadherin undergoes posttranslational regulation — it becomes concentrated at cell-cell junctions and linked to the actin cytoskeleton via catenins (alpha-catenin, beta-catenin). Maternal Cdh1 knockout embryos fail to compact. (3) Polarity establishment: Simultaneously, outer cells establish apical-basal polarity. The Par complex (Par3-Par6-aPKC) localizes to the contact-free (apical) surface, while E-cadherin concentrates at the contact (basolateral) surface. This polarization is essential because at the next division (8-cell to 16-cell), cells can divide symmetrically (tangentially, producing two outer polarized cells) or asymmetrically (radially, producing one outer polarized cell and one inner apolar cell). (4) Inside-outside model: Inner (apolar) cells become ICM and outer (polarized) cells become TE. The polarity state determines Hippo signaling status and thus Cdx2 vs Oct4 expression. (5) Additional mechanisms: Tight junctions (involving ZO-1 and occludin) form between the apical surfaces of outer cells, creating a permeability seal that allows fluid accumulation to form the blastocoel cavity. (6) Ezrin and other ERM proteins help anchor the apical domain to the actin cytoskeleton.

questions.question: Researchers want to test whether the Wnt/beta-catenin pathway is necessary for dorsal axis specification in Xenopus embryos. They design an experiment using lithium chloride (LiCl), which inhibits GSK-3beta, and a dominant-negative Wnt receptor (dnFrizzled). Which experimental design would best test the hypothesis?
options: Group 1: Untreated control embryos; Group 2: Embryos treated with LiCl at the 32-cell stage (expected to dorsalize — inhibiting GSK-3 mimics Wnt activation, stabilizing beta-catenin); Group 3: Embryos injected with dnFrizzled mRNA at the 2-cell stage on the dorsal side (expected to ventralize — blocking Wnt reception prevents beta-catenin stabilization); Group 4: Embryos co-injected with dnFrizzled dorsally + LiCl treatment (expected to rescue — LiCl acts downstream of the receptor, bypassing the dnFrizzled block)
Inject beta-catenin mRNA ventrally and observe all phenotypes
Compare wild-type and albino embryos for axis formation differences
Treat embryos with LiCl only and observe if they develop normally
questions.explanation: This experimental design tests the Wnt/beta-catenin pathway at multiple levels using epistasis analysis: (1) Hypothesis: Wnt signaling via beta-catenin stabilization on the dorsal side is necessary and sufficient for dorsal axis specification in Xenopus. (2) Control group: Untreated embryos develop normally with a single dorsal axis. The dorsal side is specified during cortical rotation (first cell cycle), which translocates Dishevelled and GBP to the dorsal side, locally inhibiting GSK-3 and stabilizing beta-catenin. (3) LiCl treatment (Group 2): Lithium chloride inhibits GSK-3beta globally, stabilizing beta-catenin in all cells. This causes dorsalization — the entire embryo adopts dorsal fates, often resulting in radially dorsalized 'belly piece' embryos lacking ventral structures. In mild cases, embryos develop expanded dorsal structures and secondary axes. This demonstrates that beta-catenin stabilization is sufficient for dorsal specification. (4) dnFrizzled injection (Group 3): A dominant-negative Frizzled receptor blocks Wnt ligand reception. When injected dorsally, it prevents the normal dorsal Wnt signal from being transduced, causing ventralization — loss or reduction of dorsal structures (notochord, somites, neural tissue) and expansion of ventral fates (blood, mesenchyme). This demonstrates that Wnt signaling is necessary for dorsal specification. (5) Epistasis rescue (Group 4): LiCl inhibits GSK-3, which acts downstream of the Frizzled receptor in the pathway (Wnt → Frizzled → Dishevelled → GSK-3 inhibition → beta-catenin stabilization). Therefore, LiCl should rescue the dnFrizzled phenotype because it bypasses the blocked receptor. If dorsal structures are restored, it confirms the epistatic relationship and that the key output of Wnt signaling is GSK-3 inhibition and beta-catenin stabilization. (6) This design incorporates gain-of-function, loss-of-function, and epistasis approaches — the gold standard for pathway analysis in developmental biology.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about the role of the extracellular matrix (ECM) in embryonic development:
(I) Fibronectin is essential for mesoderm cell migration during gastrulation, and its RGD (Arg-Gly-Asp) peptide sequence is recognized by integrin receptors on migrating cells.
(II) Hyaluronic acid, a large glycosaminoglycan, creates hydrated spaces in the ECM that facilitate cell migration and tissue expansion, as seen in neural crest migration pathways and cardiac jelly formation.
(III) Basal lamina (basement membrane) components including laminin and type IV collagen provide structural support and signaling cues, with laminin being the first ECM molecule deposited during development.
(IV) The ECM serves only as a passive structural scaffold and has no role in signal transduction during development.
options: TTFT
TTTT
TFTT
TTTF
questions.explanation: The extracellular matrix plays dynamic and essential roles throughout embryonic development: (1) Statement I is TRUE: Fibronectin is a large glycoprotein that forms a fibrillar network in the ECM. During gastrulation, migrating mesoderm cells require fibronectin as a substrate. The RGD (Arg-Gly-Asp) tripeptide within fibronectin's type III repeat domains is recognized by integrin receptors (particularly alpha5beta1) on migrating cells. Blocking fibronectin with antibodies or injecting RGD peptides to competitively inhibit integrin binding disrupts gastrulation movements in Xenopus and chick embryos. Fibronectin fibrillogenesis on the blastocoele roof is essential for mesoderm migration. (2) Statement II is TRUE: Hyaluronic acid (hyaluronan) is an exceptionally large, unbranched GAG that does not bind to a core protein but exists freely in the ECM. Its enormous water-binding capacity creates swollen, hydrated spaces that physically open migration pathways and expand tissues. In cardiac development, hyaluronan-rich cardiac jelly separates the myocardium from the endocardium and is essential for valve and septum formation. Neural crest cells migrate through hyaluronan-rich pathways, and hyaluronidase treatment disrupts their migration. (3) Statement III is TRUE: Laminin is among the earliest ECM molecules expressed during development, detectable even in the 2-cell stage mouse embryo. It is a heterotrimeric glycoprotein (alpha, beta, gamma chains) that self-assembles on cell surfaces and serves as the scaffold for basement membrane assembly. Laminin interacts with cells via integrin receptors and dystroglycan, providing adhesion, polarity, and signaling cues. Type IV collagen provides structural integrity to the basement membrane. (4) Statement IV is FALSE: The ECM is far from a passive scaffold. It actively participates in signal transduction by: (a) sequestering and releasing growth factors (FGFs, BMPs, Wnts bind to heparan sulfate proteoglycans), (b) activating integrin signaling pathways (FAK, Src, Ras-MAPK) that regulate cell survival, proliferation, and differentiation, (c) providing mechanical signals (mechanotransduction through integrins), and (d) serving as a substrate for morphogen gradient formation.

questions.question: Morphogen gradients are fundamental to pattern formation. The French Flag model proposes that cells read morphogen concentrations to adopt different fates. Which of the following best describes how the Bicoid morphogen gradient functions in Drosophila anterior-posterior axis patterning?
options: Bicoid is uniformly distributed throughout the embryo and activates all target genes equally

Bicoid mRNA is localized at the anterior pole by dynein-mediated transport along microtubules; after translation, Bicoid protein forms an anterior-to-posterior concentration gradient through diffusion and degradation, functioning as a transcription factor that activates anterior gap genes (hunchback) at high concentrations and represses posterior genes (caudal mRNA translation) — different target gene promoters have different numbers and affinities of Bicoid binding sites, enabling concentration-dependent threshold responses
Bicoid gradient is established by active transport of the protein from posterior to anterior
Bicoid acts only as a translational repressor and does not function as a transcription factor
questions.explanation: The Bicoid morphogen system is the best-characterized morphogen gradient in developmental biology: (1) mRNA localization: bicoid mRNA is localized to the anterior cortex of the Drosophila oocyte during oogenesis. This localization depends on the 3'UTR of bicoid mRNA and involves dynein-mediated transport along microtubules, as well as trapping by Staufen protein at the anterior. (2) Gradient formation: After fertilization, bicoid mRNA is translated, and Bicoid protein diffuses posteriorly from the anterior source while being simultaneously degraded. This creates an exponentially declining anterior-to-posterior concentration gradient with a characteristic length of approximately 100 micrometers (about 20% of embryo length). The gradient reaches steady state within approximately 90 minutes. (3) Transcription factor function: Bicoid is a homeodomain transcription factor. It binds to specific DNA sequences (Bicoid binding sites) in the promoters/enhancers of target genes. The key target is hunchback (hb) — the hb promoter contains multiple Bicoid binding sites that act cooperatively, creating a sharp on/off threshold for hb transcription at about 50% egg length. (4) Concentration-dependent targets: Different genes require different concentrations of Bicoid for activation. High-affinity binding sites in certain enhancers are activated at low Bicoid concentrations (more posteriorly), while low-affinity sites require high concentrations (activated only anteriorly). This enables concentration-dependent readout of a single gradient. (5) Translational repression: Bicoid also functions as a translational repressor — it binds to the 3'UTR of caudal mRNA (via its homeodomain, recognizing an RNA structural element) and represses its translation in the anterior. This allows Caudal protein to accumulate only in the posterior, where it activates posterior gap genes. (6) The SDD (Synthesis-Diffusion-Degradation) model explains gradient formation, though recent evidence suggests that nucleocytoplasmic shuttling and pre-steady-state dynamics also contribute to gradient shape.

questions.question:
A gene expression study measured mRNA levels of key transcription factors during Xenopus gastrulation. The following data was obtained:

Gene | Dorsal lip expression | Ventral expression | Function
Chordin | +++ | - | BMP antagonist
Noggin | ++ | - | BMP antagonist
BMP4 | - | +++ | Ventral mesoderm/epidermis inducer
Goosecoid | +++ | - | Homeodomain TF, organizer marker
Vent1/2 | - | +++ | BMP target, ventral fate
Sox2 | ++ | - | Neural progenitor marker

Which conclusion about dorsal-ventral axis patterning is best supported by this data?
options: BMP4 induces neural tissue on the dorsal side

The data supports the default model of neural induction, where the dorsal organizer secretes BMP antagonists (Chordin, Noggin) that create a BMP-free zone dorsally — in the absence of BMP signaling, dorsal ectoderm adopts neural fate (Sox2+) by default, while ventral ectoderm receiving BMP4 signaling activates Vent1/2 and becomes epidermis, and ventral mesoderm adopts ventral fates (blood, lateral plate mesoderm)
Goosecoid directly activates BMP4 expression ventrally
Sox2 expression is induced by high BMP4 concentrations
questions.explanation: This data beautifully illustrates the default model of neural induction and BMP-mediated dorsal-ventral patterning: (1) Default neural induction: The revolutionary insight from the 1990s (Hemmati-Brivanlou and Melton) was that ectoderm cells become neural by default when BMP signaling is absent. Dissociated ectodermal cells (which lose autocrine BMP signaling) spontaneously express neural markers. The organizer's role is to locally inhibit BMP signaling, allowing dorsal ectoderm to follow its default neural pathway. (2) BMP antagonists at the organizer: Chordin (+++ dorsal) binds BMP4 with high affinity and prevents it from activating its receptors (BMPR-I and BMPR-II). Noggin (++ dorsal) similarly sequesters BMPs. Follistatin (not shown) also antagonizes BMPs. These secreted antagonists create a BMP activity gradient — low dorsally (organizer), high ventrally. (3) BMP4 ventral expression: BMP4 (+++ ventral) signals through type I and type II serine/threonine kinase receptors to activate Smad1/5/8 transcription factors. Smad1/5/8 dimerize with Smad4 and activate ventral target genes including Vent1 and Vent2 (+++ ventral), which are homeobox transcription factors that promote ventral-posterior mesoderm and epidermal fates while repressing dorsal genes. (4) Goosecoid (+++ dorsal): A homeodomain transcription factor that is one of the first genes activated in the organizer by the combined input of beta-catenin (from Wnt/cortical rotation) and Nodal signaling. Goosecoid can directly repress ventral genes including BMP4 and Wnt8. (5) Sox2 (++ dorsal): A key neural progenitor transcription factor. Its dorsal expression confirms that neural induction occurs in the BMP-free zone. Sox2 is initially activated by FGF signaling and maintained by the absence of BMP — constitutive BMP signaling blocks Sox2 and drives epidermal fate. (6) The complementary expression patterns (dorsal organizer genes vs ventral BMP targets) perfectly reflect the morphogen gradient model of axis patterning.

questions.question: Genomic imprinting results in parent-of-origin-specific gene expression. Which of the following correctly explains the mechanism and developmental consequences of imprinting at the Igf2/H19 locus?
options: The paternal allele expresses Igf2 (growth factor) while the maternal allele expresses H19 (non-coding RNA), regulated by differential methylation of the imprinting control region (ICR) — on the maternal allele, the unmethylated ICR binds CTCF insulator protein which blocks the downstream enhancer from accessing Igf2, directing it instead to H19; on the paternal allele, ICR methylation prevents CTCF binding, allowing the enhancer to activate Igf2 while H19 is silenced by spreading methylation
Both Igf2 and H19 are expressed from both parental alleles
The maternal allele always expresses Igf2 and the paternal allele always expresses H19
Imprinting at this locus is controlled by histone acetylation only
questions.explanation: The Igf2/H19 locus is the paradigmatic example of genomic imprinting regulation: (1) Genomic organization: On mouse chromosome 7 (human chromosome 11p15.5), the Igf2 gene (encoding Insulin-like Growth Factor 2) and H19 gene (encoding a long non-coding RNA) are located approximately 90 kb apart, separated by an imprinting control region (ICR, also called the differentially methylated region, DMR). Shared enhancers lie downstream of H19. (2) Maternal allele: The ICR is unmethylated. The zinc-finger protein CTCF (CCCTC-binding factor) binds to the unmethylated ICR (which contains 4 CTCF binding sites). CTCF acts as an insulator, creating a chromatin loop that blocks the downstream enhancers from physically interacting with the Igf2 promoter. Instead, the enhancers activate H19. Result: maternal allele expresses H19, Igf2 is silent. (3) Paternal allele: The ICR is methylated (established during spermatogenesis by DNMT3A/DNMT3L). Methylation prevents CTCF binding. Without the insulator, the downstream enhancers can access and activate the Igf2 promoter. Meanwhile, methylation spreads from the ICR to the H19 promoter, silencing H19. Result: paternal allele expresses Igf2, H19 is silent. (4) Parental conflict hypothesis: IGF2 is a potent growth factor — the paternal allele promotes fetal growth (benefiting paternal reproductive fitness), while the maternal H19 (which may act as a tumor suppressor and limit growth) counterbalances this. This aligns with the kinship/parental conflict theory of imprinting (Haig). (5) Disease relevance: Loss of imprinting at this locus causes Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (biallelic Igf2 expression — overgrowth, tumor predisposition) or Silver-Russell syndrome (biallelic H19/loss of Igf2 — growth restriction). (6) The CTCF-insulator model was confirmed by deletion experiments — removing the ICR on the maternal allele causes Igf2 activation, and inserting ectopic CTCF sites can create new insulator boundaries.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about axis determination in the chick embryo:
(I) The anterior-posterior axis of the chick embryo is determined before gastrulation by the posterior marginal zone (PMZ), which expresses Vg1 (GDF1) and Wnt8C, and induces primitive streak formation through Nodal signaling.
(II) Gravity plays a role in axis determination — as the egg rotates in the oviduct, the yolk rotates so that the blastoderm sits on top, and this tilting helps establish asymmetry by displacing the blastoderm relative to the yolk.
(III) Koller's sickle, located at the posterior edge of the area pellucida, contains cells equivalent to the amphibian Nieuwkoop center and is essential for initiating gastrulation.
(IV) The anterior region of the primitive streak (Hensen's node) is the chick equivalent of the Spemann organizer and can induce a secondary axis when transplanted to an ectopic site.
options: TTFT
TTTF
TFTT
TTTT
questions.explanation: All four statements about chick axis determination are true: (1) Statement I is TRUE: The posterior marginal zone (PMZ) is a crescent-shaped region at the posterior edge of the blastoderm that acts as the inducing center for primitive streak formation. The PMZ expresses Vg1 (GDF1, a TGF-beta family member) and Wnt8C. Vg1 signals through Activin/Nodal receptors to induce Nodal expression in the overlying epiblast, which triggers the cascade leading to primitive streak formation. Transplanting the PMZ to an anterior or lateral position induces an ectopic primitive streak. The anterior marginal zone actively inhibits streak formation by expressing the Nodal antagonist Cerberus. (2) Statement II is TRUE: As the egg travels through the oviduct (over approximately 20 hours), it rotates along its long axis. The blastoderm, floating on top of the yolk, is tilted by this rotation, and the tilting creates an asymmetry. The posterior side (where the streak will form) is consistently on the side that was tilted down. This was demonstrated experimentally by von Baer and later confirmed by rotating eggs in culture — gravitational tilting consistently biases the site of streak formation. (3) Statement III is TRUE: Koller's sickle is a thickened crescent of cells at the posterior edge of the area pellucida (where it meets the area opaca). It contains cells that ingress beneath the epiblast to form the hypoblast. These cells have inducing activity similar to the Nieuwkoop center in Xenopus — they produce signals (Vg1, Wnts) that induce the overlying epiblast to form the primitive streak. Ablation of Koller's sickle prevents normal gastrulation. (4) Statement IV is TRUE: Hensen's node, at the anterior tip of the fully formed primitive streak, is functionally equivalent to the Spemann organizer. It expresses Chordin, Noggin, and other BMP antagonists. Transplanting Hensen's node to an ectopic site induces a secondary axis, with host tissue contributing to the secondary neural tube (non-cell-autonomous induction), directly paralleling the Spemann-Mangold organizer transplant experiment.

questions.question: A researcher hypothesizes that Notch signaling is required for maintaining the oscillatory clock driving somitogenesis. They design experiments using a conditional Notch inhibitor (DAPT, a gamma-secretase inhibitor) applied to presomitic mesoderm (PSM) explants in culture. Which experimental approach would most rigorously test this hypothesis?
options: Overexpress Notch intracellular domain constitutively in all PSM cells

Group 1: Untreated PSM explants cultured in vitro (expect periodic Hes7/Lfng expression oscillations with period matching in vivo somite formation rate); Group 2: PSM explants treated with DAPT from the start (expect loss of oscillatory gene expression — Hes7 and Lunatic fringe cycles should dampen or freeze — and disruption of somite boundary formation); Group 3: PSM explants treated with DAPT, then washed and cultured without inhibitor (expect recovery of oscillations if the clock mechanism can reinitiate, or permanent disruption if Notch-dependent synchronization is irreversibly lost); Group 4: PSM explants from a Hes7-luciferase reporter line to enable real-time bioluminescence imaging of oscillation dynamics
Apply DAPT to fully formed somites and look for changes
Compare somite number between wild-type and Notch heterozygous mice at birth
questions.explanation: This experimental design rigorously tests Notch's role in the segmentation clock: (1) Background: The clock-and-wavefront model of somitogenesis proposes that an oscillating gene expression pattern (the clock) in PSM cells interacts with a moving wavefront of differentiation (defined by opposing FGF/Wnt and RA gradients) to periodically define somite boundaries. In mouse, the oscillation period is approximately 2 hours, matching the rate of somite formation. (2) Notch pathway oscillations: Key oscillating genes include Hes7 (a Notch target and transcriptional repressor), Lunatic fringe (Lfng, a glycosyltransferase that modulates Notch receptor sensitivity), and Delta-like1 (Dll1, a Notch ligand). The oscillation mechanism involves a negative feedback loop: Notch activation induces Hes7, which represses its own transcription (delayed negative feedback due to intron splicing and protein/mRNA instability creates oscillations). Lunatic fringe oscillations modulate Notch sensitivity cyclically. (3) Group 1 (control): Untreated PSM explants maintain oscillations ex vivo for several cycles, demonstrating the cell-autonomous nature of the clock. Real-time reporters (Hes7-luciferase or GFP) reveal traveling waves of gene expression sweeping from posterior to anterior PSM. (4) Group 2 (DAPT treatment): DAPT inhibits gamma-secretase, which is required for proteolytic cleavage and nuclear translocation of the Notch intracellular domain (NICD). Without NICD, Notch target genes (Hes7, Lfng) are not activated. Prediction: oscillations should cease, and somite boundaries should fail to form properly, potentially causing fused or irregular somites. (5) Group 3 (washout): Tests reversibility. If oscillations recover, it suggests the clock mechanism is robust and can reinitiate. If they do not recover, it suggests that Notch-dependent intercellular synchronization (coupling between neighboring oscillators via Delta-Notch signaling) is required to maintain coherent tissue-level oscillations, and that once cells desynchronize, they cannot resynchronize autonomously. (6) Group 4 (real-time imaging): The Hes7-luciferase reporter provides quantitative, real-time data on oscillation period, amplitude, and phase coherence — enabling measurement of precisely when and how oscillations are disrupted rather than relying on endpoint analysis. (7) This design covers loss-of-function (DAPT), recovery (washout), and quantitative dynamics (reporter), providing robust mechanistic evidence.

questions.question:
Researchers studying limb bud patterning performed the following ZPA (zone of polarizing activity) transplantation experiments in chick embryos:

Experiment | Manipulation | Digit pattern (anterior to posterior)
Control | No manipulation | 2-3-4
A | ZPA grafted to anterior margin | 4-3-2-2-3-4 (mirror image duplication)
B | Bead soaked in Shh placed anteriorly | 4-3-2-2-3-4 (identical to ZPA graft)
C | ZPA graft + cyclopamine (Shh inhibitor) | 2-3-4 (normal, no duplication)
D | Two ZPA grafts (anterior + posterior) | 4-3-2-2-3-4 (same as single anterior graft)

Which interpretation best explains these results?
options: Digit identity is determined by distance from the apical ectodermal ridge only
Shh acts as a mitogen rather than a morphogen in the limb
The ZPA acts by cell contact-dependent signaling only

Sonic hedgehog (Shh) is the morphogen produced by the ZPA that specifies digit identity in a concentration-dependent manner — an anterior ZPA graft or Shh bead creates a second source, generating a mirror-image Shh gradient and duplicated digits; cyclopamine blocks Shh signaling, abolishing the graft's effect; and two opposing ZPA sources produce the same mirror pattern as a single anterior graft because the digit pattern is determined by the local Shh concentration experienced by each progenitor cell
questions.explanation: These classic experiments demonstrate that Shh from the ZPA acts as a morphogen for anteroposterior limb patterning: (1) Normal patterning: The ZPA is a small group of cells at the posterior margin of the limb bud. These cells express Sonic hedgehog (Shh), which diffuses anteriorly to create a posterior-high to anterior-low concentration gradient. Different digits are specified at different Shh concentration thresholds: digit 4 (highest Shh, most posterior), digit 3 (intermediate), digit 2 (lowest, most anterior). Digit 1 (thumb) forms independently of Shh. (2) Experiment A — anterior ZPA graft: When the ZPA is transplanted to the anterior margin, a second source of Shh is created. This generates a mirror-image gradient — now both anterior and posterior margins have high Shh, with the lowest concentration in the middle. The resulting digit pattern (4-3-2-2-3-4) is a perfect mirror duplication, with posterior-type digits at both margins. This was first demonstrated by Saunders and Gasseling (1968). (3) Experiment B — Shh bead: A bead soaked in recombinant Shh protein placed anteriorly produces an identical mirror-image duplication, proving that Shh itself is the active morphogen (not some other ZPA-derived factor). This was shown by Riddle et al. (1993) when they identified Shh as the polarizing activity. (4) Experiment C — cyclopamine: Cyclopamine binds Smoothened (Smo), the transmembrane signal transducer in the Hedgehog pathway, and blocks its activity. When applied with a ZPA graft, cyclopamine abolishes the duplicating effect, confirming that the graft acts through Shh signaling. The normal posterior digits are maintained because endogenous Shh is also blocked, and digit formation reverts to a default pattern. (5) Experiment D — two ZPA sources: Two opposing ZPAs produce the same mirror pattern as a single anterior graft because the digit pattern depends on local Shh concentration. With two sources, the concentration profile is symmetric (high at both ends, low in the middle), identical to experiment A. Having more total Shh does not change digit identity — only the local concentration matters. (6) Mechanism: Shh signals by binding the receptor Patched (Ptc1), relieving its inhibition of Smoothened. Smoothened activates Gli transcription factors (Gli1, Gli2 — activators; Gli3 — cleaved to a repressor in absence of Shh). High Shh activates Gli2 (activator) and blocks Gli3 processing (removing repressor), while low Shh allows Gli3 repressor formation. The ratio of Gli activator to repressor determines digit identity.

questions.question: Gastrulation movements differ dramatically across animal phyla. Which of the following correctly matches the gastrulation mechanism with its primary cellular basis?
options: Invagination is driven by chemotaxis of cells toward an external signal source
Convergent extension requires no cytoskeletal activity
All gastrulation movements in all species use the same cellular mechanism

Epiboly in zebrafish involves the thinning and spreading of the blastoderm over the yolk cell, driven primarily by radial intercalation of deep cells (reducing blastoderm thickness) and actomyosin contraction at the yolk cell margin (yolk syncytial layer), while ingression at the primitive streak in amniotes involves individual cells undergoing epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) mediated by Snail/Slug transcription factors that repress E-cadherin
questions.explanation: Different gastrulation mechanisms rely on distinct cellular processes: (1) Epiboly in zebrafish: The blastoderm (initially sitting as a cap on top of the large yolk cell) must spread to envelop the entire yolk. This involves: (a) Radial intercalation — deep cells in the blastoderm rearrange by moving from inner layers to outer layers, effectively thinning the blastoderm and increasing its surface area. (b) The enveloping layer (EVL) at the surface spreads by cell flattening and possibly division. (c) The yolk syncytial layer (YSL) — a syncytium at the margin of the blastoderm — drives epiboly through actomyosin contraction. An actin band at the YSL margin contracts like a purse string, pulling the blastoderm vegetally. Microtubules in the YSL also contribute by directing vesicle trafficking toward the vegetal pole. (2) Ingression at the primitive streak (amniotes): In chick and mouse, gastrulation occurs at the primitive streak. Epiblast cells move toward the streak, undergo EMT, and ingress (individually delaminate) to form mesoderm and endoderm. The EMT is controlled by: (a) Snail and Slug (Snail2) — zinc-finger transcription factors that directly repress E-cadherin transcription. Loss of E-cadherin disrupts cell-cell adhesion, enabling cells to delaminate. (b) FGF signaling — activates Snail expression and promotes EMT. FGFR1 mutant mice fail to undergo EMT at the primitive streak. (c) RhoA downregulation — allows cells to lose apical-basal polarity and acquire mesenchymal morphology. (3) Other mechanisms: Involution (Xenopus) — cells roll over the blastopore lip and migrate internally as a coherent sheet. Invagination (sea urchin) — inward buckling of an epithelial sheet, driven by apical constriction of bottle cells. Convergent extension — cells intercalate mediolaterally, driven by polarized protrusive activity regulated by the PCP (planar cell polarity) pathway. (4) Each mechanism requires specific cytoskeletal activities, adhesion molecule regulation, and signaling pathways.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about programmed cell death (apoptosis) in development:
(I) Apoptosis during development is executed primarily through the intrinsic (mitochondrial) pathway, where pro-apoptotic Bcl-2 family members (Bax, Bak) permeabilize the outer mitochondrial membrane, releasing cytochrome c which activates caspases.
(II) In C. elegans, 131 of 1090 somatic cells generated during development undergo programmed cell death, and the core pathway involves CED-9 (Bcl-2 homolog, anti-apoptotic) inhibiting CED-4 (Apaf-1 homolog), which when released activates CED-3 (caspase).
(III) BMP signaling triggers apoptosis in the interdigital mesenchyme of vertebrate limbs, sculpting the digits — blocking this apoptosis (as occurs naturally in duck webbed feet) results in tissue retention between digits.
(IV) Developmental apoptosis is a pathological process that occurs only when cells are damaged or infected.
options: TTTF
TTFT
FTTT
TFTT
questions.explanation: Apoptosis is an essential, genetically programmed component of normal development: (1) Statement I is TRUE: The intrinsic (mitochondrial) pathway is the primary apoptotic mechanism in development. When a cell receives a death signal (or lacks survival signals), pro-apoptotic BH3-only proteins (Bid, Bim, Bad, etc.) activate the effectors Bax and Bak. Bax/Bak oligomerize and form pores in the outer mitochondrial membrane (MOMP — mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization), releasing cytochrome c into the cytoplasm. Cytochrome c binds Apaf-1, which assembles into the apoptosome — a heptameric wheel-shaped complex that recruits and activates procaspase-9 (initiator caspase). Active caspase-9 then cleaves and activates executioner caspases (caspase-3, -7), which cleave cellular substrates (DNA fragmentation factor, lamins, PARP) leading to orderly cell dismantling. Anti-apoptotic Bcl-2 family members (Bcl-2, Bcl-xL) prevent MOMP by sequestering pro-apoptotic members. (2) Statement II is TRUE: C. elegans development produces exactly 1090 somatic cells, of which 131 undergo programmed cell death (discovered by Sulston and Horvitz, Nobel Prize 2002). The core pathway: EGL-1 (BH3-only protein) is transcriptionally activated in cells fated to die. EGL-1 binds CED-9 (Bcl-2 homolog), releasing CED-4 (Apaf-1 homolog) from the mitochondrial membrane. Free CED-4 oligomerizes and activates CED-3 (caspase), executing cell death. Dead cell corpses are engulfed by neighboring cells. This pathway is conserved in all animals. (3) Statement III is TRUE: In pentadactyl vertebrate limbs, the digits are initially connected by interdigital mesenchyme. BMPs (particularly BMP2, BMP4, BMP7) are expressed in the interdigital regions and trigger apoptosis in this tissue, sculpting free digits. In ducks and other webbed species, the interdigital mesenchyme expresses high levels of the BMP antagonist Gremlin, which protects these cells from BMP-induced apoptosis, resulting in webbing retention. Experimentally, applying BMP-soaked beads to chick interdigital tissue accelerates apoptosis, while applying Noggin (BMP inhibitor) prevents it. (4) Statement IV is FALSE: Developmental apoptosis is a normal, essential, genetically programmed process. It occurs in healthy, undamaged cells as part of morphogenesis and tissue remodeling. Examples include: interdigital cell death (digit separation), elimination of the tail during tadpole metamorphosis, sculpting of the nervous system (50% of neurons die during development due to insufficient neurotrophic factor support), hollowing of lumens, and deletion of structures (Mullerian duct in males, Wolffian duct in females).

questions.question:
Researchers performed lineage tracing experiments in mouse embryos using Cre-lox technology to determine the contributions of different germ layers. They crossed tissue-specific Cre driver lines with Rosa26-reporter mice and analyzed adult tissue composition:

Cre driver line | Labeled germ layer | Labeled tissues in adult
Sox17-Cre | Definitive endoderm | Gut epithelium, liver hepatocytes, pancreatic islets, thyroid follicular cells, lung alveolar epithelium
Mesp1-Cre | Mesoderm | Heart (cardiomyocytes), blood vessels (endothelium), kidneys (nephrons), skeletal muscle, dermis, bone marrow
Sox1-Cre | Neuroectoderm | Brain neurons, spinal cord, retina, peripheral ganglia (partial)
Wnt1-Cre | Neural crest | Craniofacial cartilage/bone, melanocytes, peripheral neurons/glia, adrenal medulla, cardiac outflow tract

Which conclusion about germ layer contributions is best supported?
options: All internal organs derive exclusively from endoderm
Each adult tissue derives from only one germ layer

The data confirms that while the three germ layers have characteristic derivative tissues, some organs receive contributions from multiple germ layers — for example, the gut wall contains endoderm-derived epithelium plus mesoderm-derived smooth muscle and vasculature; furthermore, neural crest (a fourth quasi-germ layer unique to vertebrates) contributes extensively to craniofacial structures, PNS, melanocytes, and cardiac outflow tract, overlapping with both ectodermal and mesodermal territories
Neural crest cells contribute only to neural tissue
questions.explanation: Cre-lox lineage tracing provides definitive evidence for germ layer fate mapping in mammals: (1) Technology: Cre recombinase expressed under a tissue-specific promoter (matching a germ layer) permanently activates a reporter gene (e.g., lacZ or GFP at the Rosa26 locus) in all cells derived from that lineage, regardless of whether the Cre promoter remains active. This allows tracking all descendants of labeled cells into adult tissues. (2) Endoderm derivatives (Sox17-Cre): The definitive endoderm gives rise to the epithelial lining of the gastrointestinal tract (from pharynx to rectum), and the parenchymal cells of associated organs: liver (hepatocytes, cholangiocytes), pancreas (both exocrine acinar cells and endocrine islet cells), thyroid (follicular cells), parathyroid, thymus epithelium, lungs (alveolar and bronchial epithelium), and bladder epithelium. Importantly, the stroma, muscle, and blood vessels of these organs are mesoderm-derived — only the epithelial/parenchymal components come from endoderm. (3) Mesoderm derivatives (Mesp1-Cre): Mesoderm gives rise to: cardiovascular system (heart, blood vessels, blood cells), musculoskeletal system (skeletal muscle from somitic myotome, bone from sclerotome, cartilage), excretory system (kidneys — nephrons from intermediate mesoderm), dermis (from dermatome of somites and lateral plate mesoderm), gonads, adrenal cortex, and serous membranes (peritoneum, pleura, pericardium). (4) Neuroectoderm derivatives (Sox1-Cre): Entire central nervous system (brain, spinal cord, retina), and some peripheral ganglia. The neural plate gives rise to the CNS through neurulation. (5) Neural crest (Wnt1-Cre): Neural crest is sometimes called the fourth germ layer because of its extraordinary multipotency. Wnt1-Cre marks midbrain and neural crest cells. Neural crest derivatives include: craniofacial bones and cartilage (unique among vertebrate skeletal elements in being ectoderm-derived), melanocytes (skin pigment cells), entire peripheral nervous system (sensory neurons, sympathetic/parasympathetic ganglia, Schwann cells, enteric nervous system), adrenal medulla (chromaffin cells), smooth muscle of cardiac outflow tract and great vessels, and dental pulp/odontoblasts. (6) Multi-germ layer organs: Most organs are composites — e.g., the intestine has endodermal epithelium, mesodermal smooth muscle and blood vessels, ectodermal enteric neurons (neural crest), and mesodermal connective tissue. The heart has mesodermal cardiomyocytes but neural crest-derived outflow tract components.

questions.question: The Hedgehog (Hh) signaling pathway uses a unique signal transduction mechanism involving the primary cilium in vertebrates. Which of the following correctly describes how Hh signaling is transduced?
options: Hedgehog signaling does not require the primary cilium in any organism
Smoothened is a ligand-gated ion channel that opens when Hedgehog binds

In the absence of Hh ligand, the receptor Patched (Ptch1) localizes to the primary cilium and inhibits Smoothened (Smo) by preventing its ciliary accumulation; Gli transcription factors are proteolytically processed to repressor forms (Gli3R) at the cilium base — when Hh binds Patched, Patched exits the cilium, allowing Smoothened to accumulate in the cilium and activate full-length Gli proteins (Gli2A) which enter the nucleus to activate target genes
Hedgehog ligand binds directly to a tyrosine kinase receptor, activating the Ras-MAPK cascade
questions.explanation: The vertebrate Hedgehog pathway is uniquely dependent on the primary cilium: (1) Primary cilium: A non-motile, microtubule-based antenna projecting from most vertebrate cells during G0/G1. It is built by intraflagellar transport (IFT) — kinesin-2 (anterograde) and dynein-2 (retrograde) move cargo along the ciliary axoneme. The cilium concentrates and organizes Hh signaling components. (2) Pathway OFF (no Hh ligand): Patched1 (Ptch1), a 12-transmembrane protein, localizes to the ciliary membrane. Ptch1 acts catalytically to inhibit Smoothened (Smo), a 7-transmembrane protein (related to Frizzled), by altering the lipid/sterol environment — Ptch1 may transport sterols (oxysterols, cholesterol) that regulate Smo activity. With Smo inhibited, it remains excluded from the cilium. Gli transcription factors (Gli2, Gli3) are transported to the cilium tip by IFT, where they are phosphorylated by PKA, CK1, and GSK3 (kinases associated with the cilium base). Phosphorylated Gli3 (and to a lesser extent Gli2) is recognized by the E3 ubiquitin ligase SCF/beta-TrCP, leading to proteasomal processing that removes the C-terminal activation domain, generating the truncated repressor forms (Gli3R, Gli2R). Gli3R enters the nucleus and represses Hh target genes. (3) Pathway ON (Hh present): Hedgehog ligand (Shh, Ihh, or Dhh) binds Patched1, causing Ptch1 to exit the cilium (internalized and degraded). This relieves Smo inhibition. Smo undergoes conformational change, is phosphorylated, and translocates into the cilium. Ciliary Smo disrupts the Gli processing complex — full-length Gli2 is now activated (Gli2A) rather than processed. Gli2A dissociates from Sufu (Suppressor of Fused, a negative regulator) at the cilium tip and translocates to the nucleus, activating target genes (Ptch1, Gli1, Hhip1, etc.). Gli1 is itself a target gene and amplifies the transcriptional response. (4) Cilium requirement: IFT mutant mice (e.g., IFT88, Kif3a knockouts) lose primary cilia and show Hh signaling defects resembling both loss and gain of function — they lose Gli activator function but also lose Gli repressor processing. This explains why cilium defects cause complex phenotypes. (5) Diseases: Mutations in ciliary genes cause ciliopathies (polycystic kidney disease, Bardet-Biedl syndrome, Joubert syndrome), many with Hh-related developmental defects. Aberrant Hh activation causes basal cell carcinoma and medulloblastoma.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about Nodal signaling in vertebrate development:
(I) Nodal is a TGF-beta superfamily ligand that signals through ActRIIB/ALK4 receptor complexes and the co-receptor Cripto (EGF-CFC family), activating Smad2/3 transcription factors.
(II) Nodal signaling is essential for mesoderm and endoderm induction — different concentrations of Nodal specify different fates, with high concentrations inducing endoderm (Sox17+) and lower concentrations inducing mesoderm.
(III) Nodal is regulated by positive feedback (Nodal activates its own transcription) and negative feedback through secreted antagonists Lefty1/2 and Cerberus, which limit the range and duration of Nodal signaling.
(IV) Nodal plays no role in left-right axis determination in vertebrates.
options: TTFT
TTTT
TTTF
TFTT
questions.explanation: Nodal signaling is a central pathway in vertebrate embryogenesis: (1) Statement I is TRUE: Nodal is a secreted TGF-beta superfamily member. It signals by binding a receptor complex consisting of type II receptor ActRIIB and type I receptor ALK4 (ActRIB), along with the essential GPI-linked co-receptor Cripto (also called TDGF1, an EGF-CFC family member). Without Cripto, Nodal cannot signal efficiently. Ligand binding activates ALK4 kinase, which phosphorylates receptor-regulated Smads (Smad2 and Smad3). Phospho-Smad2/3 complexes with Smad4 and translocates to the nucleus, where it partners with transcription factors (FoxH1/FAST, Mixer) to activate target genes. (2) Statement II is TRUE: Nodal acts as a morphogen — different concentrations specify different cell fates. In zebrafish (where Nodal homologs are Cyclops and Squint) and Xenopus, high levels of Nodal signaling induce endoderm (activating Sox17, GATA4/5/6), intermediate levels induce axial/dorsal mesoderm (activating Goosecoid, Chordin), and lower levels induce lateral/ventral mesoderm. In mouse, Nodal-null embryos fail to form mesoderm or definitive endoderm and arrest at gastrulation. The concentration-dependent response is mediated by different promoters having different affinities for Smad2-FoxH1 complexes. (3) Statement III is TRUE: Nodal signaling is regulated by interconnected feedback loops. Positive feedback: Nodal activates its own transcription through a Nodal-responsive enhancer (ASE — asymmetric enhancer), creating an autoactivation loop that amplifies the signal. Negative feedback: Nodal also induces expression of its own antagonists — Lefty1 and Lefty2 (divergent TGF-beta members that compete with Nodal for receptor/co-receptor binding but cannot activate signaling) and Cerberus (a multi-functional antagonist that also inhibits BMPs and Wnts). Leftys diffuse farther than Nodal (reaction-diffusion mechanism), creating a self-limiting signaling domain. This resembles a Turing-type activator-inhibitor system. (4) Statement IV is FALSE: Nodal plays a pivotal role in left-right axis determination. In mouse, motile cilia on the embryonic node generate leftward fluid flow (nodal flow). This leftward flow concentrates Nodal-containing vesicles/particles on the left side, activating Nodal expression specifically in the left lateral plate mesoderm. Left-sided Nodal then activates Pitx2, a homeobox transcription factor that directs left-sided organ morphogenesis (heart looping, gut rotation, spleen position). Lefty1 in the midline acts as a barrier to prevent Nodal spreading to the right side. Mutations in Nodal, Lefty, or Pitx2 cause laterality defects (situs inversus, heterotaxy).

questions.question: Digit identity in the vertebrate limb is specified by the zone of polarizing activity (ZPA) through Sonic hedgehog. However, the duration of Shh exposure, not just concentration, determines digit identity. Which mechanism best explains how temporal exposure to Shh specifies different digits?
options: Duration of exposure only affects digit size, not identity
All digits receive the same duration of Shh exposure and differ only in their receptor density
Shh acts instantaneously and temporal exposure is irrelevant

Cells nearest the ZPA are exposed to Shh for the longest duration, and sustained Shh signaling progressively activates higher-order Hox genes (HoxD10-13) through chromatin remodeling at the HoxD locus — posterior digits (4,5) require prolonged Shh exposure to fully activate late Hox genes via a switch from an early/anterior regulatory landscape (telomeric TAD) to a late/posterior landscape (centromeric TAD), while anterior digits (2,3) require only brief exposure
questions.explanation: The temporal model of Shh-dependent digit specification integrates morphogen signaling with chromatin topology: (1) Classical vs temporal model: The classical French Flag model proposed that digits are specified by different concentrations of Shh. However, elegant experiments by Harfe et al. (2004) and Zhu et al. showed that the duration of Shh exposure is equally or more important than concentration. Cells that produce Shh (or are close to the ZPA) experience it for the longest time and form digit 5, while cells progressively farther away experience shorter durations and form digits 4, 3, 2. (2) HoxD gene regulation: The five posterior Hox genes (HoxD9-13) are arranged in a cluster on chromosome 2. Their expression in the limb bud is regulated by two distinct topologically associated domains (TADs) on either side of the cluster. The telomeric (5') TAD contains enhancers that drive early, anterior-proximal expression of Hox genes (phase 1 — limb bud outgrowth, specifying arm/forearm). The centromeric (3') TAD contains enhancers (including the ZRS, zone of regulatory sequence) that drive late, posterior-distal expression (phase 2 — digit specification). (3) Chromatin switching: During limb development, the HoxD cluster transitions from telomeric TAD regulation (early, proximal) to centromeric TAD regulation (late, distal). Sustained Shh signaling is required to fully activate the centromeric enhancers and drive high-level expression of HoxD12 and HoxD13 in posterior digits. Brief Shh exposure activates only the telomeric enhancers, resulting in lower Hox expression (anterior digits). (4) Experimental evidence: (a) Conditional removal of Shh at progressively earlier time points results in loss of posterior digits first (digit 5 lost first, then 4, then 3), confirming that posterior digits require the longest exposure. (b) Lineage tracing of Shh-expressing cells shows they contribute to digits 5 and 4 but not to anterior digits. (c) Grafting experiments showed that ZPA cells transplanted for different durations produce different numbers of extra digits. (5) Downstream effectors: HoxD13 and HoxD12 are particularly important for posterior digit identity. HoxD13 mutations cause synpolydactyly in humans. The combinatorial Hox code (which combination and level of HoxD genes are expressed in each digital ray) determines digit identity through regulation of downstream targets including Runx2 (bone formation), Shox2, and Bmp genes.

questions.question:
Researchers performed heterochronic parabiosis (surgical joining) experiments between young (3-month) and old (22-month) mice and measured stem cell function:

Condition | Satellite cell activation (muscle) | Neurogenesis (SVZ) | Hepatocyte proliferation | Serum GDF11 level
Young alone | 100% (baseline) | 100% (baseline) | 100% (baseline) | High
Old alone | 35% | 25% | 40% | Low
Young-Old parabiosis (old partner) | 78% | 72% | 85% | Intermediate
Young-Old parabiosis (young partner) | 95% | 90% | 92% | Intermediate

Which conclusion is best supported by these data?
options: Aging of stem cells is entirely cell-intrinsic and cannot be reversed
Old mice have no surviving stem cells
The young partner's stem cells migrate to the old partner's tissues

The systemic environment (circulating factors in the blood) profoundly influences stem cell aging — old stem cells exposed to young blood via parabiosis show substantial rejuvenation of satellite cell activation, neurogenesis, and hepatocyte proliferation, suggesting that age-related decline in regenerative capacity is partly due to changes in circulating factors rather than irreversible stem cell damage, with GDF11 and other youth-associated factors potentially mediating this effect
questions.explanation: Heterochronic parabiosis experiments have revolutionized our understanding of aging: (1) Experimental design: Parabiosis surgically joins two mice so they share a circulatory system. Heterochronic parabiosis pairs a young mouse with an old mouse, allowing old tissues to be exposed to young blood factors and vice versa. Isochronic controls (young-young, old-old) control for the surgery itself. (2) Rejuvenation of old stem cells: The data shows that old partners in heterochronic pairs recover 78% satellite cell activation (vs 35% alone), 72% neurogenesis (vs 25% alone), and 85% hepatocyte proliferation (vs 40% alone). This demonstrates that the old stem cells are still present and competent — their reduced function is largely due to the aged systemic environment, not irreversible cell damage. (3) Satellite cells (muscle): Aged muscle stem cells (satellite cells) show impaired activation after injury. Conboy et al. (2005) showed that young blood restores Notch signaling in old satellite cells, enhancing their activation and muscle regeneration. The old muscle niche also contributes — young blood may reduce fibrosis (TGF-beta) and inflammatory signals. (4) Neurogenesis: The subventricular zone (SVZ) and hippocampal dentate gyrus are neurogenic regions where adult neural stem cells produce new neurons. Neurogenesis declines dramatically with age. Villeda et al. (2011, 2014) showed that young plasma rejuvenates neurogenesis and cognitive function in old mice, partly through reducing inflammatory factors (CCL11/eotaxin increases with age and impairs neurogenesis). (5) Hepatocyte proliferation: Liver regeneration after partial hepatectomy declines with age. Young blood restores proliferative capacity of old hepatocytes by reactivating growth factor signaling. (6) GDF11 and circulating factors: GDF11 (Growth Differentiation Factor 11, a TGF-beta family member) was initially reported as a rejuvenating factor that declines with age (Loffredo et al. 2013). However, this finding has been debated — some groups could not replicate the GDF11 decline. Other rejuvenating factors include oxytocin and TIMP2 (brain rejuvenation), while pro-aging factors include CCL11, beta-2-microglobulin, and TGF-beta. (7) Young partner effects: The young partner shows mild decreases (95%, 90%, 92% vs 100%), consistent with exposure to old blood factors causing a slight aging effect. (8) Clinical implications: These findings suggest that aging may be modifiable through targeting circulating factors, spurring interest in young plasma transfusion studies, exercise-induced factor release, and specific rejuvenating molecule identification.

questions.question: Pioneer transcription factors play a critical role in cell fate specification during development. What unique property distinguishes pioneer factors from other transcription factors?
options: Pioneer transcription factors (such as FoxA/HNF3, GATA factors, and Oct4) can bind to their target DNA sequences within compact, nucleosomal chromatin — their DNA-binding domains structurally resemble linker histones, allowing them to engage nucleosome-wrapped DNA and initiate chromatin opening by recruiting chromatin remodelers and histone modifiers, thereby enabling subsequent binding of other transcription factors that require open chromatin
Pioneer factors repress all gene expression by compacting chromatin
Pioneer factors can only bind to DNA in open chromatin regions already marked by H3K4me3
Pioneer factors function only in terminally differentiated cells
questions.explanation: Pioneer transcription factors are central to understanding how cell fate decisions overcome epigenetic barriers: (1) Definition: Pioneer factors are transcription factors that can access and bind their target DNA sequences even when the DNA is wrapped around nucleosomes in compact chromatin. This distinguishes them from most transcription factors, which can only bind to nucleosome-free (open) DNA. (2) Structural basis: FoxA (Forkhead box A, formerly HNF3), the founding pioneer factor, has a winged-helix DNA-binding domain that structurally resembles the globular domain of linker histone H1. This allows FoxA to bind the nucleosome in a manner similar to H1, but instead of compacting chromatin, FoxA displaces H1 and opens the local chromatin structure. The winged-helix domain contacts DNA on both sides of the nucleosome, stabilizing its binding to nucleosomal DNA. (3) Mechanism of chromatin opening: After binding, pioneer factors: (a) recruit ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling complexes (SWI/SNF, ISWI) that reposition or evict nucleosomes; (b) recruit histone acetyltransferases (p300/CBP) that add activating marks (H3K27ac); (c) prevent DNA methyltransferase access, leading to local demethylation; (d) create a nucleosome-free region that is then accessible to other, non-pioneer transcription factors. (4) Examples in development: (a) FoxA — essential for liver and pancreas specification; it binds and opens enhancers in the albumin locus in endoderm before hepatic genes are activated. Without FoxA, liver fate cannot be specified because the relevant enhancers remain in closed chromatin. (b) GATA factors — pioneer binding at hematopoietic enhancers enables blood cell specification. (c) Oct4, Sox2, Klf4 (Yamanaka factors) — Oct4 acts as a pioneer factor during iPSC reprogramming, accessing closed somatic cell chromatin to reactivate the pluripotency network. This is why Oct4 is the most critical Yamanaka factor and the hardest to replace. (5) Two-step model: Pioneer factor binding is the first step (competence), followed by signal-dependent activation (specification). For example, FoxA binds albumin enhancers in gut endoderm (making them competent), but actual liver gene activation requires subsequent FGF and BMP signals from the cardiac mesoderm. (6) Relevance to reprogramming: The ability of pioneer factors to access closed chromatin explains why only certain transcription factors can reprogram cell fate (e.g., the Yamanaka factors for iPSCs, MyoD for muscle).

questions.question: A developmental biologist wants to create a fate map of the mouse gastrula using modern single-cell approaches. Which experimental strategy would provide the most comprehensive spatial and temporal fate map?
options: Stain embryos with vital dyes and observe where colored cells end up

Combine CRISPR-based lineage barcoding (introducing unique heritable DNA barcodes via Cas9 at defined developmental stages) with single-cell RNA sequencing at multiple time points — barcoded cells and their descendants share the same barcode, allowing reconstruction of lineage trees, while scRNA-seq profiles reveal the transcriptional state (cell type identity) of each descendant, enabling simultaneous mapping of both lineage relationships and cell fate outcomes across the entire embryo
Use bulk RNA-seq on whole embryos at different stages
Transplant labeled cells from one embryo to another and count how many survive
questions.explanation: Modern fate mapping combines lineage tracing with single-cell genomics for unprecedented resolution: (1) Classical fate mapping limitations: Traditional methods (vital dye injection, retroviral labeling, Cre-lox genetic labeling) can trace the fate of labeled cell populations, but they are limited in throughput (only a few clones per embryo) and cannot simultaneously capture molecular (transcriptomic) state. (2) CRISPR barcoding: Technologies like MEMOIR, GESTALT, and scGESTALT use CRISPR-Cas9 to introduce unique, heritable mutations (barcodes) into defined genomic target sites. When Cas9 is expressed at a specific developmental stage, it creates unique insertion/deletion patterns at target loci. These barcodes are inherited by all daughter cells, creating a shared molecular mark. By reading the barcode sequences later (via sequencing), all cells sharing a barcode can be identified as clonal relatives (descended from the same ancestor). (3) Single-cell RNA-seq integration: Each barcoded cell is also profiled for its complete transcriptome by scRNA-seq. This reveals the cell's identity (e.g., neuron, muscle, blood) based on its gene expression profile. Combining barcode identity with transcriptomic identity allows researchers to determine: (a) which cell types derive from which progenitors (fate mapping), (b) how closely related different cell types are (lineage trees), (c) when fate decisions occur (by sampling multiple time points), and (d) what transcription factors are expressed at decision points (molecular mechanisms). (4) Computational reconstruction: Algorithms like LINNAEUS, CARLIN, and Waddington-OT reconstruct branching lineage trees from barcode similarity (cells sharing more barcodes are more closely related) and transcriptomic trajectories. This creates a comprehensive fate map linking spatial origin, lineage history, and terminal cell fate across the entire embryo. (5) Spatial transcriptomics: Complementary techniques like MERFISH, seqFISH+, and Slide-seq add spatial coordinates, allowing mapping of where progenitors and descendants physically reside. Combining spatial transcriptomics with lineage barcoding provides a complete 4D (space + time) fate map. (6) Recent applications: Chan et al. (2019) used this approach in mouse embryos to trace tens of thousands of clones through gastrulation, revealing unexpected lineage relationships and the timing of germ layer commitment. Pijuan-Sala et al. (2019) used scRNA-seq time courses of mouse gastrulation to build a molecular atlas of cell fate trajectories.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about the role of microRNAs (miRNAs) in developmental timing:
(I) In C. elegans, the heterochronic pathway controlling larval stage transitions involves the miRNAs lin-4 and let-7, which repress target mRNAs (lin-14, lin-28, lin-41) to ensure proper temporal progression of cell fate programs.
(II) lin-4 miRNA, discovered in 1993, was the first microRNA identified and acts by binding to complementary sequences in the 3'UTR of lin-14 mRNA, leading to translational repression and mRNA destabilization.
(III) let-7 miRNA is highly conserved across bilaterians and regulates the larval-to-adult transition in C. elegans and homologous developmental timing processes in other organisms.
(IV) MicroRNAs have no role in vertebrate development and function only in C. elegans.
options: TTTF
TTFT
TTTT
TFTT
questions.explanation: MicroRNAs were discovered through the study of developmental timing in C. elegans: (1) Statement I is TRUE: The heterochronic pathway in C. elegans controls the temporal sequence of cell fate programs during larval development (L1 through L4 to adult). Mutations in heterochronic genes cause cells to adopt fates from the wrong larval stage — either precocious (adopting later fates too early) or retarded (reiterating earlier fates). lin-4 and let-7 are miRNAs within this pathway. lin-4 miRNA targets lin-14 and lin-28 mRNAs for downregulation, enabling progression from L1 to later fates. let-7 miRNA targets lin-41, hbl-1, and lin-28 mRNAs, enabling the L4-to-adult transition. Loss of lin-4 or let-7 causes heterochronic phenotypes — cells reiterate earlier programs. (2) Statement II is TRUE: lin-4 was identified by Victor Ambros's lab in 1993 as a small RNA (~22 nucleotides) transcribed from the lin-4 locus. Lee, Feinbaum, and Ambros showed that lin-4 has complementarity to repeated elements in the 3'UTR of lin-14 mRNA. This was the first demonstration that a small RNA regulates another gene post-transcriptionally. lin-4 binding causes translational repression (ribosomes are stalled or not recruited) and accelerated mRNA degradation. This discovery predated the understanding of miRNAs as a general regulatory mechanism by nearly a decade. (3) Statement III is TRUE: let-7 miRNA was identified by Reinhart et al. (2000) and remarkably, its sequence is perfectly conserved from C. elegans to humans. In C. elegans, let-7 accumulates in L4 and triggers the adult fate program. In Drosophila, the let-7-Complex (let-7, miR-100, miR-125) regulates developmental timing during metamorphosis. In vertebrates, let-7 family members regulate cell proliferation, differentiation, and stem cell maintenance. let-7 is downregulated in many cancers (acting as a tumor suppressor), and its targets include oncogenes like Ras, Myc, and HMGA2. Lin28 (a let-7 target in C. elegans) represses let-7 maturation in vertebrate stem cells, maintaining self-renewal — let-7 upregulation upon Lin28 downregulation promotes differentiation. (4) Statement IV is FALSE: MicroRNAs are ubiquitous regulators in vertebrate development. The miRNA processing enzyme Dicer is essential — Dicer-null mouse embryos die at E7.5. Specific miRNAs regulate: heart development (miR-1, miR-133), brain patterning (miR-9, miR-124), limb development (miR-196), hematopoiesis (miR-223, miR-150), and immune cell differentiation (miR-155, miR-181). Over 2000 miRNAs have been identified in the human genome, collectively regulating approximately 60% of protein-coding genes.

questions.question:
Researchers studying neural tube closure defects (NTDs) collected epidemiological data and performed genetic studies:

Factor | Effect on NTD risk | Mechanism
Folic acid supplementation | 70% reduction in NTD incidence | Provides methyl groups for DNA methylation and nucleotide synthesis
Mutation in Vangl2 (PCP gene) | 15-fold increase in NTD risk | Disrupts convergent extension during neural plate folding
High maternal temperature (fever) | 2-3 fold increase | Disrupts heat-sensitive developmental processes
Valproic acid exposure | 10-fold increase | HDAC inhibitor alters gene expression patterns
Pax3 mutation | Severe NTDs (splotch phenotype in mice) | Disrupts dorsal neural tube specification

Which interpretation best explains the multifactorial nature of neural tube defects?
options: NTDs are caused by a single gene defect and environmental factors are irrelevant
NTDs occur randomly with no genetic or environmental component
All NTDs can be prevented by folic acid alone

NTDs have a complex multifactorial etiology involving gene-environment interactions — genetic variants in planar cell polarity (PCP) pathway genes, neural tube patterning transcription factors, and folate metabolism enzymes interact with environmental risk factors (folate deficiency, teratogens, hyperthermia), reflecting the fact that neural tube closure requires precise coordination of convergent extension movements, apical constriction, dorsolateral hinge point bending, and midline fusion — disruption at any step can cause failure
questions.explanation: Neural tube defects illustrate the multifactorial threshold model of developmental disorders: (1) Neural tube closure process: Neurulation involves: (a) neural plate bending at the median hinge point (MHP, driven by Shh from the notochord inducing apical constriction), (b) elevation of neural folds, (c) convergent extension of the neural plate (narrowing and lengthening, driven by PCP pathway), (d) dorsolateral hinge point (DLHP) bending, (e) neural fold contact and fusion at the midline, and (f) separation of neural tube from surface ectoderm. Closure initiates at multiple sites — in mice, there are 4 closure initiation sites, and failure at each produces distinct NTD types. (2) PCP pathway (Vangl2): The planar cell polarity pathway (Vangl1/2, Celsr1, Dvl, Fzd3/6) controls convergent extension — mediolateral intercalation of cells that narrows the neural plate. Loss of Vangl2 (Loop-tail mutation in mice) prevents convergent extension, leaving the neural plate too wide to close, causing craniorachischisis (complete open neural tube). Over 300 genes cause NTDs in mouse models, and many are PCP components. In humans, rare variants in VANGL1, VANGL2, CELSR1, and other PCP genes are found in NTD patients. (3) Folic acid: The 70% reduction with supplementation is one of the most successful public health interventions in developmental biology. Folate is essential for: (a) thymidylate synthesis (DNA replication in rapidly dividing neural progenitors), (b) S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) production for DNA and histone methylation (epigenetic regulation of neural genes), and (c) homocysteine metabolism. Mutations in folate metabolism genes (MTHFR C677T variant, affecting 10-15% of some populations) increase NTD risk by reducing 5-methyltetrahydrofolate production. Folic acid bypasses this bottleneck. (4) Valproic acid: An anticonvulsant drug that inhibits histone deacetylases (HDACs), causing hyperacetylation and aberrant gene expression during critical neural tube closure windows. The 10-fold risk increase makes it one of the most potent human teratogens for NTDs. The mechanism involves disruption of Wnt, Shh, and RA-responsive gene expression. (5) Pax3 (splotch mouse): Pax3 is a paired-box transcription factor essential for dorsal neural tube specification and neural crest development. Pax3 mutations cause failure of DLHP formation and neural crest migration defects. Human PAX3 mutations cause Waardenburg syndrome (neural crest defects). (6) Threshold model: NTDs result when the combined genetic and environmental risk factors exceed a threshold. An individual with mild PCP variants may be protected by adequate folate, but combined with folate deficiency or teratogen exposure, the threshold is crossed. This explains why folic acid prevents most but not all NTDs (those caused by severe genetic defects may exceed the threshold regardless of folate status).

questions.question: The Spemann-Mangold organizer experiment (1924) is considered one of the most important in developmental biology. What specific result demonstrated that the organizer acts by induction rather than self-differentiation?
options: When a dorsal lip from a pigmented donor was transplanted to the ventral side of an unpigmented host, the resulting secondary axis contained both pigmented (donor) and unpigmented (host) tissues — critically, the secondary nervous system was composed primarily of unpigmented host cells, demonstrating that the transplanted organizer induced neighboring host cells to change their fate from epidermis to neural tissue rather than simply self-differentiating into all structures
The host developed normally despite the transplant
The transplanted organizer tissue developed into a complete second embryo by self-differentiation
The transplanted cells died and had no effect on the host
questions.explanation: The Spemann-Mangold experiment is foundational to the concept of embryonic induction: (1) Experimental design: Hilde Mangold (student of Hans Spemann) transplanted the dorsal lip of the blastopore from a pigmented newt (Triturus taeniatus, darkly pigmented) to the ventral side of an unpigmented host (Triturus cristatus, lightly pigmented). This allowed the donor and host cells to be distinguished by their pigmentation. (2) Key result: A secondary (Siamese twin) body axis formed on the ventral side of the host, containing a notochord, neural tube, somites, and other axial structures. Critically, analysis of cell pigmentation revealed that the notochord was derived from donor (pigmented) cells (self-differentiation of the transplant), but the secondary neural tube was composed predominantly of host (unpigmented) cells. The somites were a mixture. (3) Significance of induction: The fact that host ventral cells (normally fated to become epidermis and ventral mesoderm) were recruited to form neural tissue (a dorsal fate) demonstrates induction — the organizer emitted signals that changed the developmental fate of neighboring cells. If the organizer had simply self-differentiated into all structures of the secondary axis, all tissues would have been pigmented (donor-derived). The presence of host-derived neural tissue proves a non-cell-autonomous (inductive) effect.
