(4) Nobel Prize: Spemann received the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1935 for the discovery of the organizer effect. Mangold had died in 1924 (a kitchen accident) and could not share the prize. (5) Molecular basis (discovered 70 years later): The organizer's inductive activity is mediated by secreted BMP antagonists (Chordin, Noggin, Follistatin) that create a BMP-free zone, allowing the default neural fate to emerge in dorsal ectoderm. Additional signals include Wnt antagonists (Dickkopf, Frzb, Cerberus) for head induction and Nodal-related signals for mesoderm patterning. (6) Conservation: Organizer transplant experiments produce secondary axes in all vertebrate models tested — chick Hensen's node, zebrafish shield, and mouse node — confirming the universal nature of this inductive mechanism.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about Wnt signaling pathway variants in development:
(I) The canonical Wnt/beta-catenin pathway promotes axis specification by stabilizing beta-catenin, which enters the nucleus and partners with TCF/LEF transcription factors to activate target genes including Axin2 and c-Myc.
(II) The non-canonical Wnt/PCP (planar cell polarity) pathway does not involve beta-catenin and instead activates RhoA and Rac1 GTPases through Dishevelled, regulating cytoskeletal dynamics and convergent extension during gastrulation.
(III) The Wnt/calcium pathway activates PLC (phospholipase C) through heterotrimeric G-proteins, leading to intracellular calcium release, CamKII activation, and NFAT-mediated transcription.
(IV) All three Wnt pathway variants use the same set of Frizzled receptors and downstream effectors with identical outcomes.
options: TTTF
TTFT
TTTT
TFTT
questions.explanation: The Wnt signaling family comprises at least three distinct pathways with different effectors: (1) Statement I is TRUE: In canonical Wnt signaling, Wnt ligands (e.g., Wnt1, Wnt3a, Wnt8) bind Frizzled receptors and the co-receptor LRP5/6. This recruits Dishevelled (Dvl), which inhibits the destruction complex (APC-Axin-GSK3-CK1). Without destruction complex activity, beta-catenin is not phosphorylated (normally, sequential phosphorylation by CK1 and GSK3 marks beta-catenin for ubiquitination by beta-TrCP and proteasomal degradation). Stabilized beta-catenin accumulates and enters the nucleus, where it displaces the co-repressor Groucho from TCF/LEF transcription factors, converting them from repressors to activators. Key targets include Axin2 (negative feedback), c-Myc (cell proliferation), Cyclin D1, and various developmental genes. This pathway is critical for axis specification (dorsal beta-catenin in Xenopus and zebrafish), stem cell maintenance (intestinal crypt ISCs require Wnt signaling), and organogenesis. (2) Statement II is TRUE: The Wnt/PCP (planar cell polarity) pathway is activated by non-canonical Wnt ligands (Wnt5a, Wnt11) binding Frizzled (without LRP5/6). Dishevelled is recruited but signals through different downstream effectors: (a) Dvl activates DAAM1 (Dishevelled-Associated Activator of Morphogenesis 1), which activates RhoA → ROCK (Rho-Associated Kinase), regulating actomyosin contractility. (b) Dvl activates Rac1 → JNK (c-Jun N-terminal Kinase), regulating actin polymerization and protrusive activity. These cytoskeletal changes drive convergent extension — cells intercalate mediolaterally by extending polarized lamellipodia in the mediolateral direction. Loss of PCP genes (Vangl2, Celsr1, Dvl) causes severe convergent extension defects and neural tube closure failure. (3) Statement III is TRUE: The Wnt/calcium pathway involves Wnt ligand binding to Frizzled, activating heterotrimeric G-proteins. G-protein alpha subunit activates PLC (phospholipase C), which cleaves PIP2 into IP3 and DAG. IP3 triggers calcium release from the ER, activating CamKII (calcium/calmodulin-dependent kinase II) and calcineurin. Calcineurin dephosphorylates NFAT (Nuclear Factor of Activated T-cells), allowing nuclear translocation and target gene activation. This pathway modulates cell adhesion and ventral fate specification. (4) Statement IV is FALSE: While all three pathways use Frizzled receptors, they differ in: (a) co-receptors (LRP5/6 for canonical only; Ror2, Ryk for non-canonical), (b) downstream effectors (beta-catenin vs RhoA/Rac1 vs calcium), (c) transcriptional outcomes (TCF target genes vs JNK targets vs NFAT targets), and (d) Wnt ligand specificity (Wnt3a is canonical, Wnt5a is typically non-canonical, though context matters). The pathways can even antagonize each other — non-canonical Wnt signaling can inhibit canonical signaling through CamKII-mediated TAK1 activation or by sequestering Dishevelled.

questions.question: During vertebrate eye development, the optic vesicle induces the overlying surface ectoderm to form the lens placode. However, lens-forming competence is established well before optic vesicle contact. What is the current model for multistep lens induction?
options: Only FGF signaling from the retina is required for lens induction
The optic vesicle is the sole inducer and surface ectoderm has no pre-existing competence

Lens induction occurs in multiple sequential phases: first, signals from the anterior neural plate and underlying head mesenchyme (including BMP, FGF, and Pax6 activation) establish a lens-competent domain in the head ectoderm (lens bias); second, direct contact between the optic vesicle and surface ectoderm provides a final inductive signal (FGF and BMP from the optic vesicle) that activates Sox2 and the definitive lens program — Pax6 in the surface ectoderm is both necessary and sufficient for lens competence, as Pax6-null ectoderm cannot form lens even when contacted by optic vesicle
Lens formation is entirely cell-autonomous and requires no inductive signals
questions.explanation: Lens induction is a paradigmatic example of progressive tissue competence and multi-step induction: (1) Lens competence (bias phase): Before the optic vesicle contacts the surface ectoderm, head ectoderm acquires lens-forming competence through signals from underlying tissues. In chick, BMP and FGF signals from the anterior neural plate and head mesenchyme activate Pax6 expression in a broad domain of head ectoderm. Pax6 is the master regulator of lens and eye development — ectopic Pax6 expression can induce ectopic eyes (Halder et al. 1995, using Drosophila eyeless). Without Pax6, the surface ectoderm cannot respond to optic vesicle signals. (2) Experimental evidence for multi-step induction: (a) If the presumptive lens ectoderm is transplanted away from the optic vesicle early, it cannot form lens — it requires optic vesicle contact. (b) If non-head ectoderm is placed over the optic vesicle, it usually cannot form lens — it lacks lens competence (Pax6 expression). (c) However, if Pax6 is ectopically expressed in non-head ectoderm and placed near optic vesicle signals, lens markers can be activated. (3) Optic vesicle contact (specification phase): The optic vesicle closely apposits the surface ectoderm. Signals from the optic vesicle include: (a) FGFs — particularly FGF15 and FGF19, which activate Ras-MAPK signaling in the ectoderm. (b) BMP4 and BMP7 — secreted by the optic vesicle, which activate Smad signaling. These combined signals, acting on Pax6-competent ectoderm, activate Sox2 and the transcription factor L-Maf/c-Maf, initiating the definitive lens program. (4) Lens placode formation: Activated lens ectoderm thickens to form the lens placode, which invaginates to form the lens vesicle. Crystallin gene expression begins (alpha-crystallins first, then beta and gamma). (5) Reciprocal induction: The lens also signals back to the optic vesicle, inducing it to form the optic cup (the future retina and retinal pigmented epithelium). Without lens signals, the optic vesicle fails to invaginate properly. This is a classic example of reciprocal induction — each tissue induces the other. (6) FGF gradient in the eye: After the lens vesicle separates, a gradient of FGF from the retina specifies lens polarity: high FGF posteriorly induces lens fiber cell differentiation (elongation, crystallin accumulation, organelle loss), while low FGF anteriorly maintains lens epithelial stem cells. This gradient persists throughout life, ensuring continuous lens growth.

questions.question:
Researchers studying dosage compensation across species compiled the following data:

Organism | Sex chromosomes | Mechanism | Gene expression outcome
Drosophila | XX/XY | Hyperactivation of male X (MSL complex + roX RNA) | Male X expression doubled
C. elegans | XX/XO | Downregulation of both X in XX hermaphrodites (DCC complex) | Each X reduced by half
Mammals | XX/XY | X-inactivation — one X in XX females is silenced (Xist lncRNA coats inactive X) | One active X in both sexes
Birds | ZW/ZZ | Incomplete dosage compensation — Z-linked genes show male-biased expression | 1.2-1.6 fold male bias

Which conclusion about dosage compensation is best supported?
options: All organisms use the same dosage compensation mechanism
Only mammals have evolved dosage compensation

Dosage compensation has evolved independently in different lineages using distinct molecular mechanisms — all converge on the goal of equalizing X-linked (or Z-linked) gene expression between sexes, but Drosophila achieves this by upregulating the single male X, C. elegans by downregulating both hermaphrodite X chromosomes, mammals by silencing one female X via the long non-coding RNA Xist, while birds have only partial compensation — these diverse solutions to the same problem reflect convergent evolution of gene regulatory mechanisms
Dosage compensation is unnecessary because sex chromosomes carry no important genes
questions.explanation: Dosage compensation is a remarkable example of convergent evolution in gene regulation: (1) The problem: In species with heteromorphic sex chromosomes (XX/XY or ZW/ZZ), one sex has two copies of the larger sex chromosome while the other has one. Since most X-linked (or Z-linked) genes are unrelated to sex determination and are essential housekeeping or developmental genes, a twofold dosage imbalance would be lethal or severely deleterious. (2) Drosophila — male hyperactivation: In males (XY), the Male-Specific Lethal (MSL) complex (MSL1, MSL2, MSL3, MOF histone acetyltransferase, MLE helicase) binds to the single X chromosome, guided by non-coding RNAs (roX1 and roX2). MOF acetylates H4K16 (histone H4 lysine 16 acetylation), which opens chromatin and doubles transcription from the male X. Females (XX) do not assemble the MSL complex because MSL2 translation is repressed by the sex-determination factor SXL (Sex-lethal). (3) C. elegans — hermaphrodite downregulation: In XX hermaphrodites, the Dosage Compensation Complex (DCC) — structurally related to the condensin complex — binds both X chromosomes and reduces transcription from each by approximately half. The DCC includes SDC proteins (SDC-1, SDC-2, SDC-3) and DPY proteins. In males (XO), the DCC does not assemble on the single X, which is transcribed at full level. The net result: XX animals express X-linked genes at approximately the same level as XO males. (4) Mammals — X-inactivation (Mary Lyon, 1961): In XX females, one X chromosome is transcriptionally silenced during early development. The process is initiated by the long non-coding RNA Xist (X-Inactive Specific Transcript), which is expressed from the future inactive X, coats the chromosome in cis, and recruits silencing factors: PRC2 (Polycomb Repressive Complex 2, deposits H3K27me3), PRC1, SPEN/SHARP (transcriptional repressor), and SMCHD1. DNA methylation is later added to CpG islands for maintenance. The choice of which X to inactivate is random in eutherian mammals (resulting in mosaicism — e.g., calico cats), while in marsupials, the paternal X is always inactivated (imprinted X-inactivation). (5) Birds — incomplete compensation: Unlike the other systems, birds (ZW females/ZZ males) have only partial dosage compensation. Most Z-linked genes show 1.2-1.6 fold higher expression in males (ZZ) than females (ZW). The DMRT1 locus on the Z chromosome is particularly interesting — higher DMRT1 dosage in ZZ embryos is thought to determine male sex, while lower dosage in ZW determines female sex. Some local compensation exists near the MHM (Male Hypermethylated) locus, but genome-wide compensation is incomplete. (6) Evolutionary convergence: These four mechanisms evolved independently to solve the same dosage problem, using completely different molecular machinery (histone acetylation, condensin complex, lncRNA-mediated silencing, or partial/no compensation). This highlights the strong selective pressure for dosage balance and the plasticity of gene regulatory evolution.

questions.question: A team wants to determine whether the mesoderm-inducing signals during Xenopus gastrulation require direct cell contact or act through diffusible molecules. Which experimental approach would best distinguish between these two mechanisms?
options: Sequence the genomes of dorsal and ventral cells
Simply observe gastrulation in intact embryos under a microscope

Use a Transwell co-culture system: place vegetal pole explants (endoderm, the signaling source) on one side of a porous filter membrane (0.4 micrometer pores — too small for cell processes but permeable to secreted molecules) and animal cap explants (ectoderm, the responding tissue) on the other side — if mesoderm markers (Brachyury/Xbra) are induced in the animal cap through the filter, the signal is diffusible; if not, direct cell contact is required; include controls with animal caps cultured alone (negative) and in direct contact with vegetal cells (positive)
Inject BrdU into all cells and measure proliferation rates
questions.explanation: The Transwell filter assay is the definitive approach for distinguishing contact-dependent from diffusible signaling: (1) Experimental rationale: If a signal requires direct cell-cell contact (e.g., via transmembrane ligands like Delta-Notch or Ephrin-Eph), it cannot pass through a physical barrier. If the signal is a secreted, diffusible molecule, it can pass through a porous membrane and still induce the responding tissue. (2) Transwell system: A 0.4 micrometer pore filter allows passage of molecules up to approximately 100 kDa in solution but prevents cell processes (which are typically 0.5-10 micrometers in diameter) from crossing. By placing inducing tissue on one side and responding tissue on the other, the spatial separation eliminates contact while allowing diffusion. (3) Controls: (a) Negative control — animal cap alone: Xenopus animal cap ectoderm cultured in isolation differentiates into epidermis (default atypical epidermis). It should not express mesoderm markers (Xbra/Brachyury, a T-box transcription factor marking pan-mesoderm). (b) Positive control — direct contact: Animal cap placed directly on top of vegetal explant (conjugate/recombinant) — this should induce mesoderm robustly, confirming the inducing capacity of the vegetal cells. (4) Expected result for Xenopus mesoderm induction: Classic experiments (Slack, Gurdon, and others) showed that mesoderm induction CAN occur through filters, indicating that the primary inducers are diffusible secreted factors. The key inducers were subsequently identified as members of the TGF-beta superfamily: Nodal-related proteins (Xnr1, Xnr2, Xnr4, Xnr5, Xnr6) and VegT-induced Activin/Nodal signaling from the vegetal pole. These are secreted proteins of approximately 12-25 kDa (as processed dimers) that readily diffuse through 0.4 micrometer pores. (5) Refinements: (a) Different pore sizes can distinguish between small diffusible molecules and larger complexes or vesicles. (b) Conditioned medium experiments (medium from vegetal explant cultures applied to animal caps) further confirm that the signal is secreted. (c) Adding specific inhibitors (SB431542 for Nodal/Activin pathway, or dominant-negative receptors) to the medium can identify the signaling pathway. (6) Historical significance: This type of experiment was fundamental in demonstrating that Nieuwkoop's signal (vegetal to marginal zone induction) is mediated by secreted TGF-beta family members, leading to the identification of Nodal as the key mesoderm inducer in vertebrates.

questions.question: Chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-seq) has revealed that many developmental gene promoters in embryonic stem cells carry bivalent chromatin domains. What are bivalent domains and what is their developmental significance?
options: Bivalent domains exist only in cancer cells and are not found in normal development

Bivalent chromatin domains carry both the activating mark H3K4me3 (deposited by Trithorax/MLL complexes) and the repressive mark H3K27me3 (deposited by Polycomb Repressive Complex 2/PRC2) simultaneously at the same locus — these genes are maintained in a poised, transcriptionally silent but activation-ready state in stem cells, and upon differentiation signals, the bivalent state resolves: lineage-appropriate genes lose H3K27me3 and become fully active, while lineage-inappropriate genes lose H3K4me3 and become stably silenced
Bivalent domains contain DNA methylation and H3K4me3 at the same promoters
Bivalent domains are regions with only activating marks that drive constitutive gene expression
questions.explanation: Bivalent chromatin is a key epigenetic mechanism for maintaining developmental plasticity: (1) Discovery: Bernstein et al. (2006) used ChIP-seq in mouse embryonic stem cells (ESCs) and found that many developmental gene promoters (encoding transcription factors, signaling molecules, and morphogens) simultaneously carry H3K4me3 (a mark of active promoters) and H3K27me3 (a mark of PRC2-mediated repression). This was unexpected because these marks were thought to be mutually exclusive. (2) H3K4me3: Deposited by Trithorax group (TrxG) complexes, particularly SET1/MLL methyltransferases (MLL1-4, SET1A/B). H3K4me3 marks active gene promoters and is recognized by the TAF3 subunit of TFIID, facilitating transcription initiation. At bivalent genes, H3K4me3 is present but not sufficient for transcription because PRC2-mediated repression dominates. (3) H3K27me3: Deposited by PRC2 (Polycomb Repressive Complex 2), specifically by its catalytic subunit EZH2 (or EZH1). PRC2 also contains SUZ12, EED (which binds H3K27me3 and promotes spreading), and RBBP4. H3K27me3 recruits PRC1 (via its chromodomain subunit CBX), which ubiquitinates H2AK119 and compacts chromatin. At bivalent genes, PRC2-mediated H3K27me3 silences transcription despite the presence of H3K4me3. (4) Poised state: The simultaneous presence of both marks maintains developmental genes in a poised state — silent but rapidly activatable. This is critical for stem cell pluripotency because: (a) the genes are not expressed prematurely (preventing premature differentiation), (b) but they can be rapidly activated upon receiving differentiation signals (maintaining developmental potential). (5) Resolution during differentiation: When ESCs receive lineage-specifying signals: (a) Genes needed for the chosen lineage lose H3K27me3 (PRC2 is displaced, and H3K27me3 is removed by demethylases like UTX/KDM6A and JMJD3/KDM6B). The remaining H3K4me3 allows full transcriptional activation. (b) Genes for alternative lineages lose H3K4me3 and gain additional repressive marks (DNA methylation, H3K9me3), becoming permanently silenced. (6) Functional evidence: Deletion of PRC2 components (EZH2, EED) in ESCs causes derepression of bivalent genes, spontaneous differentiation, and loss of pluripotency. Deletion of MLL2 (which deposits H3K4me3 at bivalent genes) causes delayed activation of developmental genes upon differentiation. (7) Prevalence: Approximately 2,000-3,000 promoters are bivalent in human ESCs, including key developmental regulators (HOX genes, SOX genes, GATA genes, T-box factors). Most of these are resolved upon differentiation, with only a subset remaining bivalent in adult stem cells.

questions.question:
Evaluate the following statements about signaling centers in limb development:
(I) The Apical Ectodermal Ridge (AER) at the distal tip of the limb bud produces FGFs (FGF4, FGF8, FGF9, FGF17) that maintain the underlying mesenchyme (progress zone) in a proliferative, undifferentiated state and are required for proximodistal outgrowth.
(II) The Zone of Polarizing Activity (ZPA) at the posterior margin produces Sonic hedgehog (Shh), which specifies digit identity along the anteroposterior axis.
(III) The dorsal and ventral ectoderm produce Wnt7a (dorsal) and En-1/BMP (ventral) respectively, establishing dorsoventral limb polarity — Wnt7a induces Lmx1b in dorsal mesenchyme, while En-1 represses Wnt7a ventrally.
(IV) The three limb signaling centers (AER, ZPA, dorsal/ventral ectoderm) operate completely independently with no cross-regulation.
options: TFTT
TTTF
TTTT
TTFT
questions.explanation: The three axes of the limb bud are patterned by interconnected signaling centers: (1) Statement I is TRUE: The AER is an epithelial ridge at the distal margin where dorsal and ventral ectoderm meet. It produces multiple FGF family members: FGF8 (the most critical — conditional deletion eliminates the limb), FGF4, FGF9, and FGF17. FGF signaling maintains the distal mesenchyme (historically called the progress zone, now better described as the distal progenitor pool) in a proliferative, undifferentiated state. Removal of the AER (by microsurgery or genetic ablation) causes limb truncation — the earlier the removal, the more proximal the truncation. FGF-soaked beads can partially substitute for the AER. (2) Statement II is TRUE: The ZPA is a small group of posterior mesenchyme cells that express Shh. Shh acts as a morphogen along the A-P axis, with highest concentration posteriorly (digits 5, 4) grading to lowest anteriorly (digit 2). Digit 1 forms independently of Shh. The ZPA's activity was discovered by Saunders and Gasseling through transplantation experiments showing mirror-image digit duplications. Shh expression is activated by dHand transcription factor and maintained by positive feedback with FGFs from the AER. (3) Statement III is TRUE: D-V patterning involves: (a) Dorsal ectoderm produces Wnt7a, which signals to the underlying dorsal mesenchyme to express Lmx1b, a LIM homeodomain transcription factor that specifies dorsal fate (tendons, hair follicles on dorsum of hand). Wnt7a-null mice have ventralized limbs (ventral paw pads on both surfaces). (b) Ventral ectoderm expresses Engrailed-1 (En-1), which represses Wnt7a ventrally, restricting Wnt7a to the dorsal ectoderm. En-1-null mice have dorsalized limbs. BMP signaling in the ventral ectoderm also contributes to ventral specification. (4) Statement IV is FALSE: The three signaling centers are highly interdependent through positive feedback loops: (a) AER-ZPA loop: FGFs from the AER maintain Shh expression in the ZPA, and Shh from the ZPA maintains FGF expression in the posterior AER (via Gremlin, a BMP antagonist — Shh → Gremlin → BMP inhibition → AER maintenance). This Shh-Gremlin-FGF circuit is the central feedback loop sustaining limb outgrowth and patterning. (b) ZPA-D/V: Wnt7a from dorsal ectoderm also helps maintain Shh expression in the ZPA. Wnt7a-null limbs lose posterior digits due to reduced Shh. (c) Termination: The feedback loop self-terminates when the AER and ZPA become too far apart (due to limb growth) for effective signaling, and when Gremlin expression is downregulated in digit-forming mesenchyme.

questions.question: During Drosophila embryogenesis, the segmentation gene cascade progressively divides the embryo into smaller units. What is the correct hierarchical order of this cascade, and how does each level of the hierarchy function?
options: The hierarchy operates in the order: maternal-effect genes (bicoid, nanos, dorsal) → gap genes (hunchback, Kruppel, knirps, giant) that define broad domains → pair-rule genes (fushi tarazu, even-skipped, hairy) that establish a periodic pattern of 7 stripes → segment polarity genes (engrailed, wingless, hedgehog) that establish anterior-posterior polarity within each of the 14 parasegments — each level interprets the preceding level's positional information and refines spatial resolution
Gap genes create 14 parasegments directly without pair-rule gene involvement
All segmentation genes act simultaneously with no hierarchy
Segment polarity genes act first, followed by gap genes, then pair-rule genes
questions.explanation: The Drosophila segmentation cascade is a paradigm for hierarchical gene regulatory networks: (1) Maternal-effect genes: These are transcribed in the mother and deposited as mRNA/protein in the egg. They establish the primary body axes. bicoid mRNA (anterior, encodes a homeodomain TF, gradient activator) and nanos mRNA (posterior, encodes a translational repressor) establish the A-P axis. dorsal mRNA (encodes an NF-kappaB-related TF, ventral nuclear localization gradient) establishes the D-V axis. These maternal gradients are read by the zygotic genome. (2) Gap genes: The first zygotic genes activated (by maternal gradients). Each gap gene is expressed in a broad domain spanning several segment-widths. hunchback — anterior domain (activated by Bicoid). Kruppel — central domain (activated by intermediate Bicoid/Hunchback levels, repressed by high Hunchback anteriorly and Knirps posteriorly). knirps — posterior-central domain. giant — two domains (anterior and posterior). Gap genes encode transcription factors that mutually repress each other, creating sharp boundaries. Gap gene mutants lack groups of contiguous segments (hence 'gap'). (3) Pair-rule genes: Activated by combinations of gap gene products. Each pair-rule gene is expressed in a pattern of 7 transverse stripes, each stripe controlled by a separate enhancer that integrates gap gene inputs. Example: even-skipped (eve) stripe 2 enhancer (the 'stripe 2 element') — activated by Bicoid and Hunchback, repressed by Giant (anteriorly) and Kruppel (posteriorly). Each stripe enhancer is a separate cis-regulatory module. Pair-rule genes are classified as primary (eve, hairy, runt — respond directly to gap gene inputs) or secondary (fushi tarazu, odd-paired — respond to primary pair-rule gene inputs). Pair-rule gene mutants show deletions in alternating segments. (4) Segment polarity genes: Activated by pair-rule gene products. These genes are expressed in 14 stripes (one per parasegment) and establish anterior-posterior polarity within each parasegment. engrailed (en) is expressed in the anterior cells of each parasegment — it encodes a homeodomain repressor. wingless (wg, a Wnt gene) is expressed in the posterior cells of the preceding parasegment. hedgehog (hh) is activated by Engrailed and signals anteriorly to maintain wingless expression, while Wingless signals posteriorly to maintain engrailed expression. This Wnt-Hedgehog positive feedback loop stabilizes the parasegment boundary. (5) Resolution: Maternal gradients provide ~100 micrometer resolution, gap genes refine to ~50 micrometer domains, pair-rule genes to ~25 micrometer stripes (2-cell wide), and segment polarity genes establish single-cell resolution within each parasegment.
